title: One 50 Brits living long Covid official data shows
story: Share this article The ONS report also showed 947,000 people were suffering with long Covid three months later.The figure was up six per cent on the 892,000 in the group on December 6.Meanwhile, 836,000 of long Covid sufferers said the symptoms affected their day-today activities on January 2 — 63 per cent of all people reporting long Covid. And 244,000 (18 per cent) said their ability to perform normal activities was 'limited a lot' because of the condition.Fatigue was the most common symptom reported, with 50 per cent of those with the condition saying they were suffering with tiredness.More than a third (37 per cent) said they had shortness of breath or a loss of smell, while 28 per cent said they had a loss of taste.Prevalence was highest for people aged 35 to 49 (2.8 per cent) and 50 to 69 (2.6 per cent).Among professions, people working in social care had the highest prevalence (3.4 per cent), followed by teaching and education (3.1 per cent) and healthcare (3 per cent).Long Covid is defined as having lingering symptoms of the virus for more than a month after infection. It is a poorly understood condition with sufferers normally reporting extreme tiredness, breathing difficulties, a loss of smell, and problems concentrating. But it has been linked to an array of other symptoms like joint pain, nausea, insomnia and depression.The number of people reporting symptoms is likely to rise in the coming months because of the swell in cases at the end of December caused by Omicron. However, Covid infections have since fallen, dropping again yesterday by 14 per cent in a week to 88,085.It came after it was reported the daily Covid update will be dropped in April under the Government's plan to live with the virus like the flu. Boris Johnson has already laid out his intention to scrap all remaining Covid laws — including the legal requirement for infected people to self-isolate — by March 24.   Experts hailed the rumoured move, arguing the Government should also push forward plans to end mass testing. Free lateral flows are not expected to be ditched until July.

title: Britains daily Covid cases bounced nearly 200 000 week symptom tracking study claims
story: Share this articleThe data comes after a separate report by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) today showed record one in 50 Brits were living with long Covid at the start of January.It estimated 1.33million adults were suffering symptoms of the wide-ranging condition as of January 2. That was up 5 per cent on the 1.26million with long Covid — defined by the ONS as having symptoms for four or more weeks after infection — on December 6.Fatigue was the most common ailment experience by sufferers, affecting half of people. The new estimate will only include the very early effects of the Omicron surge in December — because of the time it takes to develop the condition.There are concerns that long Covid prevalence could rise sharply after record numbers of people caught the disease this winter.However, it is not yet known how the mild variant's decreased severity could impact long Covid.Statisticians also estimated 554,000 were still suffering a year after catching the virus — the highest figure on record. The estimates are based on a survey of 306,000 people who self-reported suffering with long Covid, meaning they were not necessarily diagnosed. Experts have previously cast doubt over the ONS's long Covid sufferer findings, with some saying they are likely to be an overestimation given symptoms like headaches and fatigue can be linked to a variety of conditions.

title: dublin metrolink to be delayed until 2035 at the earliest
story: About €83 million has been spent so far on Link, the PAC heard.The long awaited Dublin Link will not now be completed until 2035 at the earliest, seven years after its original forecast completion date, the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) has heard.A metro linking the city by rail to the airport was first mooted in 2005. In 2018 the National Transport Authority (NTA) announced a public consultation and said it would be completed by 2027 if it succeeds at the planning stage.In October this year the Minister for Transport Eamon Ryan stated that he could not guarantee that Link would be finished by 2034.The project was included in the National Development Plan at a cost of at least €3 billion to deliver a “sustainable, safe, efficient, integrated and accessible public transport service between Swords, Dublin Airport and Dublin city centre, but no completion date was included.Speaking at the PAC on Thursday morning, Transport Infrastructure Ireland (TII) chief executive Peter Walsh said that he too could not give a completion date for the projection.The TII is in charge of building transport infrastructure projects in the State.Mr Walsh said €83 million has been spent on the Link project to date on the most recent iteration of the projection. That figure does not include fees relating to the earlier versions of the metro.He estimated that if the Government gives the go-ahead in this quarter, planning permission will be sought in the second quarter.The planning process will take at least two years, it will be followed by a two to 2½ year procurement process and then the construction would take between eight and nine years.“Across north Dublin people have lost complete faith in metro because it is a 20 year saga,” he told the committee.“The people of North Dublin are now facing a situation where at best it will be 2035 for a project which the Government is willing to fund now.“It is hugely frustrating because the Government haven’t made a decision to delay this project by 10 years, but it looks like it will be delayed by 10 years.“Not really,” Mr Walsh responded. “I take your word for you if you are frustrated.”“It is reasonable that people are frustrated by that?” Mr McAuliffe added.“People’s frustration is not something I can really comment on,” Mr Walsh said.Mr McAuliffe reminded Mr Walsh that a timeline for the project was produced in 2018 and TII was supposed to have produced the rail procurement order in the third quarter of 2019, but “failed at the first hurdle”.“Was it a realistic timeline ever or was it not resourced to the point where you could deliver it within that timeframe?” Mr McAuliffe asked.Mr Walsh said the timeline announced in 2018 was “probably optimistic. It has taken time to deal with the issues that needed to be dealt with”.Mr McAuliffe asked him why the TII could not commit to a timeline for the project. Mr Walsh stated the planning process, possible judicial reviews and procurement process were outside the power of his organisation.Mr McAuliffe said in giving no deadline for the project, it would be impossible to hold others to account for it. “It is effectively a doubling of the length of the project. We compounded the disappointment of people by a timeframe that was not realistic.”Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: paul givan set to resign as first minister of northern ireland
story: Paul Givan’s expected resignation comes amid the DUP’s protest against the Northern Ireland protocol and follows Edwin Poots’s decision to order a halt to agri-food checks at Northern Ireland’s ports. Photograph: Brian LawlessPAFirst Minister of Northern Ireland Paul Givan is expected to announce his resignation by the end of the week, a senior Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) source has said.It comes amid the party’s protest against the Northern Ireland protocol and follows his colleague Edwin Poots’s decision to order a halt to agri-food checks at Northern Ireland’s ports.It is understood that senior DUP figures are meeting later to confirm the timing of Mr Givan’s resignation statement, which could come as early as Thursday, according to PA news agency.The resignation of the First Minister would automatically remove Sinn Féin Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill from office.In those circumstances, other ministers in the administration could still remain in place. However, the Executive could not make any significant decisions.That would prevent the coalition from agreeing a three-year budget – a spending plan that is out for public consultation.A planned official state apology by Mr Givan and Ms O’Neill to victims of historic institutional abuse, scheduled for March, may also not happen.DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson has repeatedly threatened to bring down the Stormont institutions in protest against the so-called Irish Sea border, introduced as part of the post-Brexit protocol.Post-Brexit checksMr Poots issued a unilateral direction on Wednesday evening, instructing officials to stop the agri-food checks at midnight. However, there has been no confirmation from Stormont officials whether they intend to comply with the order.DUP rivals at Stormont insist Mr Poots’s direction is unlawful and civil servants are obliged to follow the law at all times.The European Commission has said the decision by the DUP Minister of Agriculture Mr Poots creates “further uncertainty and unpredictability for businesses and citizens”.An EU spokesperson said: “The European Commission has been working tirelessly with the UK government to address practical challenges related to the implementation of the protocol. The decision by the Northern Irish Minister for Agriculture is therefore unhelpful.“The European Commission will closely monitor developments in Northern Ireland pursuant to this announcement.”Vice-president of the European Commission Maros Sefcovic is due to meet UK foreign secretary Liz Truss on Thursday afternoon to continue talks on the protocol.“He will recall that controls on goods arriving in Northern Ireland from Great Britain are a key element of the protocol,” the spokesperson said. “They are necessary for Northern Irish business and citizens to continue to benefit from access to the single market for goods. They are also necessary to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland.”Belfast PortLorries were still being received at a Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs checking facility in Belfast Port earlier on Thursday morning.Several vehicles entered the facility after the ferry arrived from Cairnryan in Scotland at 6am.A staff member declined to confirm whether the agri-food checks required under the protocol were continuing.The picture is further clouded due to the fact some of the port checks have been delegated to local council staff, while UK Border Force personnel also have a presence at the facilities. It is unclear what would happen to their roles if the agriculture department staff withdrew.Mr Poots’s direction only relates to the sanitary and phytosanitary checks required by the protocol. The customs procedures on Irish Sea trade are unaffected by his instruction.Announcing the move on Wednesday, Mr Poots said legal advice he had sought on the issue supported his view that he was entitled to stop the checks.The UK government has said it will not intervene in what it has characterised as a matter that falls within the Stormont Executive.Government critics dispute this contention, highlighting that the UK has a duty under international law to abide by the terms of the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement. – PA

title: poots s order to halt post brexit checks breaches international law
story: The North’s Minister for Agriculture has ordered that post-Brexit checks at Northern Ireland’s ports are to be halted from midnight tonight.  Video: Reuters Oireachtas TVNorthern Irish Minister of Agriculture Edwin Poots: ‘A decision to initiate or continue such checks could not be validly taken in the absence of Executive approval.’ Photograph: Niall CarsonPAEdwin Poots, the North’s Minister of Agriculture, has ordered his officials to halt post-Brexit checks at ports as part of the DUP’s campaign against the Northern Ireland protocol.Mr Poots said he took the decision, which would apply to some agri-food coming into the North from Britain, after he received legal advice stating there was “presently no Executive approval” for sanitary and phytosanitary checks.It is not yet clear if the department’s permanent secretary Anthony Harbinson would comply with the order. Asked if the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs (Daera) would follow the Minister’s order, a spokesman said: “The Minister has received senior counsel advice and has issued an instruction on that basis.”Lorries were still being received at a Daera checking facility in Belfast Port earlier on Thursday morning. Several vehicles entered the facility after the ferry arrived from Cairnryan in Scotland at 6am.A staff member declined to confirm to the PA news agency whether the Northern Ireland Protocol checks were continuing.Announcing his ordering of a halt to the checks, Mr Poots told reporters on Wednesday that “a decision to initiate or continue such checks could not be validly taken in the absence of Executive approval” and therefore the advice “concluded that I can direct the checks to cease”.“I have now issued a formal instruction to my permanent secretary to halt all checks that were not in place on December 31st, 2020, from midnight tonight.”He said he would prepare a paper for the Northern Ireland Executive’s consideration “in the near future to seek agreement on a way forward”.Move condemnedThe move was strongly condemned by the Irish Government and by Sinn Féin, the SDLP and the Alliance Party, who questioned the legal basis for Mr Poots’s action and said it was more about politics than attempting to find a solution to the issues around the protocol.Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney said such a move would be “a breach of international law”.He said the protocol was part of an international agreement, and “to deliberately frustrate obligations under that treaty would be a very serious matter indeed”.“It would be essentially playing politics with legal obligations,” he said, and urged that the negotiations between the UK and the European Union on the protocol should be allowed to continue.Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill described it as a “stunt” and an “attempt by the DUP to unlawfully interfere with domestic and international law”.It is understood the UK government has been in touch with the Northern Executive and is considering the details, including the legal position. A UK government spokesman appeared to indicate it would not seek to intervene, saying “the operation of checks” was a matter for the Executive, adding that there were “significant problems with the protocol which urgently need fixing”.UK foreign secretary Liz Truss is to speak to European Commission vice-president Maros Sefcovic on Thursday, the spokesman said.

title: boriss betrayal revolutionary brexit mandate now almost total
story: This is the week a Government that began with such promise finally lost its soul. Its great policy relaunch is a tragic mush, proof that it no longer really believes in anything, not even its own self-preservation. Conservative supporters, keen to move on from Partygate, were desperate for a comprehensive package of conservative ideas to enrich the North, relaunch Brexit and pave the way for an electoral resurgence. It was not to be.Michael Gove’s levelling-up blueprint is a grotesque disappointment, a list of buzzwords and targets masquerading as strategy, its pseudo-intellectual veneer and cod history intended to camouflage the fact that it essentially advocates the very same nostrums that ultimately destroyed Labour.A proper conservative approach to levelling-up would focus on schooling, and the heart-breaking results of the white working class. It would investigate family policy and the values crisis. It would create dozens of libertarian pro-business areas, run by development corporations, with almost no taxes and regulation. It would target cheaper energy. It would liberate an extra one per cent of Britain’s landmass for house building. It would tackle the failed monolith that is the NHS. It would not see spending on public transport as a panacea. It would reject targets, subsidies and bureaucracies. It would break with socialism.Instead, Torsten Bell of the Left-wing Resolution Foundation, Britain’s most influential economics think-tank despite our nominally Tory administration, describes Johnsonian levelling up as a fusion between George Osborne and New Labour. “The agenda combines the devolution of the former Conservative Chancellor with the last Labour government’s biggeractivist central state reprioritising spend towards deprived areas”, as he puts it.A central problem is that too many Tories now have a vested interest in pretending that the form of devolution practiced in this country has been a success. This is the very reverse of the truth.Competition between local jurisdictions works, but only if set up correctly. Britain’s flawed model encourages bailouts from Westminster, grants power without fiscal responsibility and encourages municipal socialism. It doesn’t incentivise local leaders to improve competitiveness, or to think carefully enough about spending projects.Eurosceptics were always opposed to Labour’s flawed devolution: The North East Says No campaign, which defeated John Prescott’s devolution drive in 2004, was a dry run for the Brexit referendum, and included figures who went on to work for Vote Leave.The Tories also have not answered a fundamental contradiction: why do they want to make everywhere like London, given that our capital voted Corbyn and Remain? Left to its own devices, London would self-destruct, imposing punitive taxes and chasing away its value-creators. Sadiq Khan, the Mayor of London, is at it again, threatening to shut roads and tube services if he isn’t bailed out. We need more Canary Wharfs, created before devolution, and fewer City Halls.In the US, the Republicans don’t want to turn the whole of America into New York or San Francisco – they look instead at Texas or Florida. We need to replicate the brilliant bits of London, its ability to create jobs and wealth, without the socialism and cultural Left-wingery. If the Tories really believed in local accountability, they would break London up into several competing entities, not create yet more dysfunctional, statist, subsidy-hungry, rotten boroughs all over the country.If the establishment technocrats are getting everything they want, the Right has been left with almost nothing, including on Brexit. The scale of the betrayal is staggering. The Brexit white paper is one of the most shameful economic policy documents ever produced by a Conservative government. Margaret Thatcher’s Bruges Speech, Christopher Booker’s Mad Officials, Brian Hindley’s Better Off Out, the Open Europe deregulatory reports, Business for Britain’s Change or Go: all targeted over-regulation. Yet that powerful intellectual movement, built over decades, has virtually zero presence in the Remainers’ Brexit being delivered by Johnson.There have, of course, been major changes on immigration and foreign policy, and the vaccination success would not, in practice, have happened had we been part of the EU. That alone means that it was worth it, though the agricultural reforms are flawed. The decision to allow Hong Kongers to settle would also have been politically impossible had EU free movement still existed.But when it comes to the economy, the Government’s policy barely differs from Theresa May’s Brexit in name only. The authors of the 2016 Treasury attacks on Brexit have triumphed: they argued that there was very little in Britain’s tax, spend and regulatory structure that needed to be changed, and, staggeringly, Johnson’s government now agrees.All of which brings us to energy policy, another case study in extreme failure. A sensible government would urgently accelerate its nuclear plans by creating a powerful agency modelled on the vaccines taskforce. As a temporary solution, such an administration would also push to extract more oil and gas, including by fracking.Instead, a government that no longer believes in markets will now simply pretend that prices are much lower than they are. The Treasury will lend billions to energy companies to allow them to moderate price rises customers will then pay higher bills in the future to ensure the Treasury (hopefully) recoups its money.The furlough and bailouts that accompanied Covid – necessary evils given state-mandated lockdowns – have perverted our politics, undermining self-reliance and normalising handouts.That wail you hear is the cry of Toryland: among the true believers, the long-marchers, the Eurosceptics and the free-marketeers, there is sorrow, anger and despair. We have been vanquished, but we will be back.More from NewsIslamic State leader killed in US raid in SyriaRussia-Ukraine conflict: Russia and China working to &#39offset&#39 Western sanctionsEnergy price cap rise: The key points and how Rishi Sunak will help struggling householdsWatch: Italian navy officer who led cadets in viral TikTok routine cleared of bringing forces into disreputeChina &#39subjected Indian teenager to electric shocks&#39 after abducting him from disputed borderMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: chapels should safe space says cambridge college dean slavery
story: A Cambridge college dean has said chapels should be a safe space for students in an ecclesiastical court battle to have a memorial to a donor linked to slavery removed. Jesus College, Cambridge, wants to remove a plaque to Tobias Rustat, a 17th-century royal courtier, because of his links to slavery and the impact his memorial has on the ability of College members to use the chapel.Fellows applied to the Diocese of Ely to move the plaque from the chapel to another part of the college but after alumni and other academics opposed the move, the issue was brought before a consistory court for a judge to make the decision. It is the first time a university cancel culture row will be heard in court.The row has seen fellows at Cambridge pitted against academics from Oxford University. Prof Lawrence Goldman, a Jesus alumnus and an Emeritus Fellow in History St Peter's College, Oxford, opposed Jesus's application. Opponents have called Prof Nigel Biggar, a Regius Professor of Moral and Pastoral Theology at Oxford, as a witness.For opponents, attempting to remove the memorial represents an oversimplification of history and denies students the chance to think for themselves.But the college has taken the view that it represents a celebration of Rustat that is incompatible with the chapel as an inclusive community and a place of collective wellbeing.Rustat (1608-1694) was a courtier to Charles II and an investor in the Royal African Company (RAC) and the Company of Royal Adventurers, both slaving enterprises.He commissioned the memorial himself when he was already a significant benefactor to the college.Supporters of retaining the monument, including Dr Goldman, have argued that the totality of his life should be considered, not just his investments in slavery. Among his many other donations was a contribution to the reconstruction of St Paul's cathedral.Reverend James Crockford, the chapel's dean, who is responsible for the historic building, believes the memorial is a barrier to (students') participation in the chapel, the hearing was told.He told the court that there were students who did not attend the chapel because they “find it distressing to enter” and others who attended but “feel disquieted and discomfited by the presence of the memorial”.Being questioned, he was asked Do you think that church should always be a safe space? and he gave an adamant yes.But Justin Gau, the lawyer representing opponents to the memorial's removal, said: We shouldn't remove the difficulties life throws at us in a chapel, should we?.Mr Gau also suggested that adding context to the memorial to Rustat would be enough to stop it being distressing to students.For some unchurched undergraduates, he said, seeing images of Jesus, a crucified man, a dead man who had been tortured, might also be disturbing, if they didn't have the well-known context of Christianity.Mr Gau raised the role of slavery in the Bible, saying: Where, for example, in the gospels is slavery condemned?Were the memorial not to be moved, the Rev Crockford said, some of these students would be a “lot less ready to participate in the life of the chapel” and that it “would do untold damage to reputation of chapel within college” and its role in non-religious events.Historic England has warned that its removal would harm the significance of Jesus College Chapel.In 1671, Rustat donated £2,000 (approx £450,000 in today's money) to Jesus College for the education of the orphan sons of Anglican clergy.His investment in the Royal African Company is believed to have been £400. He is better known, however, for serving Charles II for 18 years, including in exile in Europe and during the English Civil War.The decision to attempt have the plaque removed came after the college set up a Legacy of Slavery Working Party (LSWP) to pursue critical self-reflection on the long-term legacies of slavery and colonial violence.The group of eight academics and two students recommended that the memorial be contextualised and its history acknowledged.The LSWP was also behind the return in 2021 of a large bronze cockerel looted from Benin City in the 19th Century.As the chapel comes under the jurisdiction of the Diocese of Ely, the college has had to petition a consistory court for permission to remove the plaque.The hearing is taking place in the chapel itself, with representatives and witnesses regularly gesturing towards and turning around in their seats to look at the memorial.The college wants to place it on permanent display elsewhere in the college alongside “contextualising” material.Alumni have also written in support of the college's application, including witness Amatey Doku - a former Cambridge Union president who was part of a group that led a five-year campaign to hand back Jesus College’s Okukor Bronze, one of the Benin Bronzes.Mr Mark Hill QC, representing the college, told the court that “This is nothing to do with erasing, cancelling or in some way nullifying the existence and the name of Tobias Rustat”.The Right Reverend Stephen Conway, the Bishop of Ely, told the hearing that the memorial needed to be removed so that current students were not reminded of the ways in which their forebears were tortured and dehumanised.Mr Gou and Mr Goldman, who is also representing the petitioners opposed, both questioned witnesses as to why the memorial could not be contextualised in situ.Sonita Alleyne, the master of Jesus College and the first black master of any Oxbridge college, told the hearing that adding context “wouldn’t take the memorial out of a position of veneration”.Mr Gau said Mr Rustat was a generous benefactor of the college and that, despite his very small involvement in the slave trade, there was now a black female master of the college.Ms Alleyne replied: How much sin do you need to have before you come off the wall?Defenders of Rustat have previously insisted that only a small fraction of his wealth ever came from slavery and that he was not directly or actively involved in it.Speaking in the hearing, Mr Gau said that students had made incorrect statements about Rustat’s involvement.Mr Gau referred to a phrase often repeated in students' emails: It's totally wrong for the statue of someone who was so heavily involved in the horrific crimes of slavery to be glorified in the heart of our community.And he said one email saying Mr Rustat made his money from slavery and caused immeasurable human suffering was incorrect.The Rev Crockford replied: It's my understanding that he did make some of his money from slavery.A student's email dated December 19 2020 said Mr Rustat amassed much of his wealth from the RAC, which Mr Gau said is simply not true.Another email from an undergraduate expressed strong support for the removal of the memorial, and claimed Mr Rustat has been clearly demonstrated as a very active slave trader.Mr Gau said there was no demonstration in any document that Tobias Rustat was any sort of slave trader.The Rev Crockford said: Not perhaps in the narrow definition of the word.The hearing will continue on Thursday.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine conflict: Russia title: plaid cymru demands end quirky names farm called hakuna matata
story: Plaid Cymru has demanded an end to “quirky” non-traditional names after a farm named “Hakuna Matata” replaced the original Welsh title on an Ordnance Survey map.Sara Davies bought a plot of empty land, originally named Banc Cornicyll, near Gorslas, Carmarthenshire, in 1997.She built a house on the land and named the property with the Swahili phrase, which means “there are no troubles” and is used in the Disney film The Lion King.Now it has emerged that this change means the original name no longer appears anywhere on the Ordnance Survey map.Speaking to Wales Online, Mrs Davies said that the name, Banc Cornicyll, had disappeared before they had purchased the land in 1997, although it is listed on documents recording the sale still on the land registry.She added: We went to the Post Office, and said we were a new-build house.They said there was no registered address for the land so we could choose to call it whatever we liked.Obviously Lion King was popular at the time, some of my husband’s friends had been working in South Africa and knew that ‘hakuna matata’ wasn’t just a Disney term but genuine Swahili and therefore it had a meaning to it.”Despite Mrs Davies saying she would never have changed the name if she knew there was a historic alternative, Plaid Cymru warned that there was a growing “trend of anglicising names”.Plaid Cymru’s rural affairs and housing spokesperson, Mabon ap Gwynfor, said: “Wales has its own language and culture. This is no clearer imprint of this than in the unique place names of many homes, farms and places across the country.“As part of safeguarding the language, there must be an end to this trend of anglicising names, and the false belief that having quirky or anglicised names makes somewhere more palatable for others.“Our place names, be they houses or fields, tells a story, a story that is unique to this corner of the world. That rich heritage is a treasure that must be valued and protected.“There must be mechanisms in place, whether that’s through planning or legislation, to help protect the language, and to reflect the valuable history of locations in Wales.”Solicitor Simon Chandler, who helped create a scheme called Diogelwn, which aims to protect Welsh names, said a lot of people simply don’t understand the importance of place names.He added: “It is important because a house name or a place name is like a time capsule.“It tells us something about the history of the land and every time we lose one of those we lose a connection with the land and the past.“A lot of people who buy houses don't necessarily understand the significance of the name.”Mr Chandler’s scheme wants those who intend to sell property to include a clause in the contract which would block buyers from changing the name.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine conflict: Russia and China working to &#39offset&#39 Western sanctionsIslamic State leader killed in US raid in SyriaEnergy price cap rise: The Key points and how Rishi Sunak will help struggling householdsWatch: Italian navy officer who led cadets in viral TikTok routine cleared of bringing forces into disreputeChina &#39subjected Indian teenager to electric shocks&#39 after abducting him from disputed borderMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: afghan christians have abandoned
story: A strange and ancient verse in the book of Deuteronomy, 26.5, has long puzzled scholars. It says, “a wandering Aramean was my father” and is at the centre of vexed and energetic Rabbinic argumentation. One obvious meaning, however, is that the Hebrew people were themselves a migrant people – as the Bible clearly indicates. Migration is, of course, part of the human story to be found in the history of the British Isles as well as the Middle East, and everywhere where there are communities of people who suffer conflict, or natural disaster.But the displacement of millions of people in recent times is unprecedented, and the sheer numbers of those risking their lives to cross the Channel even on cold mid-winter days tell a story of desperation that is experienced all over the world. Many people fear that as the world fragments into conflict and climate change places pressure on resources, migration may spiral out of control.Today a new Fund is being launched in the name of the great 20th-century wartime leader, Bishop George Bell, specifically to support persecuted Christian pastors who are refugees. George Bell famously helped Lutheran pastors who opposed Hitler and had to flee for their lives. He, together with other British humanitarians such as Sir Nicholas Winton, recognised a need and acted upon it. There are still times today when Government inaction means that private iniduals have to act in the wake of a crying need.In response to the refugee crisis, former prime minister Gordon Brown said: “We’ve got to act for moral reasons but also it’s in our own self-interest to do so.” This reminded me of Archbishop William Temple’s dictum that the art of government is the art of so ordering life that self-interest prompts what justice demands. Both are right – allowing the situation to get worse is irresponsible.Another point to note is the fear in stable societies that we might be unsettled by the consequences of allowing large numbers from other cultural traditions to settle among us. I recognise the worry which, to some degree, we all share. Clearly those who join us must recognise that they need to embrace the values, traditions and history of the host nation, just as the hosts will allow the customs of the migrants to have a place among us.We are enriched by the presence of those who have joined us in recent decades. I hope the UK will give a firm moral lead as nations respond to the crisis facing the world today.To take one example, Afghanistan is now recognised by the Open Doors charity’s “watch list” as the worst place in the world to be a Christian. In spite of the pleas of organisations working with persecuted Christians, who face the death penalty for apostasy under the country’s strict interpretation of shariah law, the Government has not taken any steps at all to allow Christians to claim asylum in the UK. We have been awaiting a long-promised announcement from ministers on how they plan to include persecuted religious minorities in resettlement schemes.Barnabas Fund Freedom of Information requests to the UK Home Office found that in the Syrian resettlement scheme, Christians were consistently underrepresented in spite of the fact that they clearly faced violence and persecution. A tiny percentage – just 0.2 per cent – of the Syrian refugees accepted by the UK in 2017 were Christian. Underlying such shameful statistics was the Home Office’s apparent admission in its own equality assessment that the effect of its policy was to “disproportionately advantage” Muslims.Several hundred Afghan Christians, including pastors and converts, are currently in hiding in neighbouring countries. They are waiting to see whether they have a place on the UK Government’s resettlement scheme.The George Bell Memorial Fund will help them flee danger, despotism and violence, and travel to safety – whether they land on British shores or elsewhere. Sometimes it takes brave humanitarians like George Bell to stand up against even our own Government and bring the persecuted to safety.George Carey is a former Archbishop of Canterbury. title: mary beard tells cheered toppling colston lifestyle depends
story: People who cheered the toppling of Edward Colston’s statue should confront the fact that their own lifestyles rely on modern slavery, Prof Mary Beard has said.The academic and television presenter said she initially felt a “thrill” when the statue of the slave trader was pulled down and thrown into Bristol’s harbour in June 2020.However, she now believes the issue is more “complicated”.Prof Beard has made a new BBC documentary series, Forbidden Art, in which she tackles censorship and controversy.“I confess in the programme - or boast - I felt a thrill,” she said of watching the statue being torn down.“I thought this had been a controversial statue for years, if not decades, and there was a bit of old-fashioned ‘public taking things into their own hands’ political protest here.“I have to say, I thought it was exciting and the right thing to do at the time. I’m not going to reject that thrill I had.”However, she went on: “Since then I’ve come to see a greater complexity to this, and in particular how the spotlight in these kinds of things is not just on Colston or any other unacceptable subject of statuary. I think the spotlight also comes down to us.“As I reflected back on my own thrill, I also realised I was sitting there with my smartphone, tweeting away and enjoying the moment, and had it crossed my mind that my smartphone was made in conditions - I don’t know if you want to call them modern slavery - but we know the exploitative conditions in which the things we rely on are made.“And I came to think that, in some ways, Colston and our feelings about him also had to work as a challenge to us.”Prof Beard said she wondered if our failure to consider what happens in foreign factories “is much the same as Colston’s sense, that we don’t really see things that are happening a very, very long way away”.She added: “Maybe we ought to look harder at ourselves… As well as deploring Colston, we might look at our own weak spots and we might wonder, I suppose, if our heroes will be toppled long after we’re dead, in a couple of hundred years’ time.“What are our faults, that will bring opprobrium onto us?”Last month, four people who admitted toppling the Colston statue walked free from court after a jury agreed that they had committed no crime.Prof Beard’s two-part series, which begins on Thursday on BBC Two, looks at art that has “challenged the political and social status quo”, including works banned by the Nazis and religious imagery.“These debates are not new. As long as there have been works of art, there have been works of art that people wanted to destroy or not see or pull down,” said Prof Beard.“We need to be a bit careful about thinking we invented the statue wars.”More from NewsIslamic State leader killed in US raid in SyriaRussia-Ukraine conflict: Russia and China working to &#39offset&#39 Western sanctionsEnergy price cap rise: The key points and how Rishi Sunak will help struggling householdsWatch: Italian navy officer who led cadets in viral TikTok routine cleared of bringing forces into disreputeChina &#39subjected Indian teenager to electric shocks&#39 after abducting him from disputed borderMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: queen would not abdicate voluntarily say royal experts
story: To mark the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee, The  hosted a panel of leading Royal experts on Wednesday night to discuss the moments that define her 70-year reign. Hosted by Camilla Tominey, Associate Editor at The , the discussion touched on the fallout from “Megxit”, the ongoing sex abuse case against Prince Andrew, and the future of the Royal Family.Royal biographer Penny Junor said the Queen has “always put the monarchy ahead of everything else”.Historian and professor Suzannah Lipscomb agreed and described Her Majesty’s attitude as “duty first and self second”.Discussing the response to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle stepping down as senior members of the family and the US court case against the Duke of York, Professor Lipscomb said the Queen has shown “integrity”.“I think it does show her protection in the end of the institution, of the family.”The panelists agreed that the Queen would not abdicate “voluntarily”, but said that Prince Charles is an “extraordinary man” who inspires genuine affection from a “huge number of people”.On the future of the monarchy, Prof Lipscomb said she believed it will be “slimmed down” to focus on the line of succession but that questions have arised about how different a man on the throne will be in contrast to the Queen’s “maternal presence”.Sustaining that relationship between the UK and the Commonwealth would really be a way of sustaining her legacy,” Prof Lipscomb added.“That's been really her greatest achievement, and she cares about it so very much.”Ms Junor said: “For the monarchy to survive, it has to be seen to be useful and fulfilling a purpose and not costing the earth and just to be worthwhile and for people to be able to relate to it.”The Queen, throughout all the cultural and political change that has occurred throughout her 70-year reign, has been an “absolute constant anchor in the midst of these seas”, Prof Lipscomb said.She said that the monarch will be remembered for her constancy, the Commonwealth, the longevity of her reign and her emphasis on reconciliation and unity.Ms Junor added: “I think she will be remembered as the mother of the nation.”More from NewsRussia-Ukraine title: raf scramble typhoon second day response aircraft approaching
story: The Royal Air Force has launched Typhoon jets after undisclosed aircraft approached what an RAF spokesman described as the UK's area of interest, a day after jets responded to four Russian strategic bombers nearing Britain.It is understood that the jets flying in the UK area of interest are Russian. Just yesterday RAF typhoons spent five hours tracking Russian aircraft who were flying in UK airspace.The spokesman confirmed that the Typhoons, launched from RAF Lossiemouth in Moray, Scotland, have been joined by a Voyager air-to-air refuelling tanker from RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire.He added that further information would not be disclosed on this ongoing operation until complete.The news comes after RAF jets responded to four Russian strategic bombers approaching the UK's area of interest on Wednesday.The bombers were intercepted and escorted, a spokesman said, and at no point did they enter UK airspace.Footage released by the Russian Ministry of Defence earlier on Thursday showed a Russian bomber, of the same type that was intercepted on Wednesday, being flanked by two RAF jets while on a planned flightMore from NewsRussia-Ukraine conflict: Russia and China working to &#39offset&#39 Western sanctionsIslamic State leader killed in US raid in SyriaEnergy price cap rise: The Key points and how Rishi Sunak will help struggling householdsWatch: Italian navy officer who led cadets in viral TikTok routine cleared of bringing forces into disreputeChina &#39subjected Indian teenager to electric shocks&#39 after abducting him from disputed borderMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: statism not route levelling
story: Visitors to Florence will have seen the six-ball emblem of the Medicis dotted around the city, attached to buildings financed by the family’s considerable fortune. Michael Gove alluded to this example of self-publicising 14th-century paternalism in his announcement yesterday of the Government’s “levelling up” proposals. The idea is that by bringing together innovators in one place, the Medicis unwittingly instigated the Renaissance.Mr Gove believes that by applying a similar model in England, left-behind parts of the country can be brought up to up to the standards of living seen in more prosperous regions. Boris Johnson, will also hope that investment directed towards these areas will be similarly badged to leave no doubt in the so-called Red Wall constituencies as to its provenance. Levelling up is the Prime Minister’s Big Idea for the parliament, but showing voters the benefits before the next election scheduled for 2024 will be a difficult task.Attracting entrepreneurs, businesses, arts venues, good schools, effective transport and the rest to areas that have hitherto struggled is clearly to be commended. The issue is how to do it. Top-down dispensation of taxpayers’ largesse to regions that for decades have relied disproportionately on the public sector for jobs is not the answer, although yet more public money was Labour’s demand, as it always is.The plan comprises a dozen pledges enshrined in statute to be achieved by 2030, with targets to reach certain benchmarks for improving outcomes. The political architecture to bring this about will involve greater devolution and the appointment of regional mayors with the powers to drive the agenda. As a former mayor, Mr Johnson clearly sees merit in this approach provided the right person is in charge. A mayor can act as a barrier to investment and development by pursuing anti-business policies. In London, and soon in Manchester and Bradford, “green” motoring charges are more likely to drive commerce away, not encourage it.The analysis of the UK as top-heavy is correct: London and the South East have a greater dominance in this country than almost anywhere else. But this is a function of the decline of manufacturing and the rise of services, not of state interventionism. If there is to be a renaissance in the regions they need competitive tax policies, freeports, deregulation and less, not more, government.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine conflict: Russia and China working to &#39offset&#39 Western sanctionsIslamic State leader killed in US raid in SyriaEnergy price cap rise: The Key points and how Rishi Sunak will help struggling householdsWatch: Italian navy officer who led cadets in viral TikTok routine cleared of bringing forces into disreputeChina &#39subjected Indian teenager to electric shocks&#39 after abducting him from disputed borderMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

news politics --misleading-claims-boris-"Boris Johnson savages Keir Starmer over LabournomicsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Boris Johnson has had a furious PMQs clash with Keir Starmer as Labour ’s leader accused him of peddling facist conspiracies and gaslighting the public”.Sir Keir hit out at the PM’s  claim, made on Monday, that as Director of Public Prosecutions he failed to prosecute paedophile Jimmy Savile. The CPS said he had no involvement in the decision. Meanwhile, he claimed it was wrong for the PM to insist the Tories are the party of low taxes at a time when heaposs squeezing working people to the pips. Things were so tense, Commons Speaker Lindsay Hoyle had to warn MPs not to accuse the PM of lying, which is unparliamentary.In his replies to Sir Keir, Boris Johnson earned roars of support from his own MPs as he trumpeted employment, GDP and wage figures.But perhaps he got a little carried away in his wording. Here are seven things he said that are either outright , or don’t stack up in context.  There are ‘more people in work than before the pandemic began’ This claim had been branded incorrect by the Office for Statistics Regulation just a day earlier in a letter to No. Director Ed Humpherson said the PM was referring to people on payrolls, but this excludes many self-employed. Mr Humpherson told Downing Street: The number of people on employer payrolls does not include everyone in work. ONS publishes data on the number of people in employment. The data for January – March  estimate that .m people were in employment compared with .m people in employment for September – November . It is therefore incorrect to state that there were more people in work at the end of this period than the start.  Tories are ‘lting the Living Wage - which this party introduced’ Tory Chancellor George Osborne introduced the National Living Wage in , but this was a rebranded version of the National Minimum Wage for over-s. That means the National Living Wage is, legally speaking, the same thing as the National Minimum Wage - which Labour introduced in . Importantly, the NLW is lower than the ‘real’ Living Wage which has been promoted for years by campaigners as the amount that meets everyday needs. The real Living Wage is currently £. or £. in London - compared to £. for the government’s National Living Wage, which will rise to £. in April. ‘In spite of all the dficulties we’ve faced, we have now got the fastest growth in the G. Absolutely true’ Technically yes, the UK’s GDP is forecast to grow by .% in  - the highest of any G country. But that is not the full picture - it also fell by .% in  according to the IMF, the worst of any G country. That means it’s now bouncing back faster too. According to the House of Commons Library, UK GDP was still down by .% in July-September  compared to pre-pandemic levels. This was the second-worst of any G country, behind Canada, Italy, Germany, the Eurozone, France and the US. The Commons Library also warned these figures are not % comparable across countries due to dferences in how output in the education and health sectors is calculated. ‘We’re getting , people off welfare and into work through our Way to Work plan’Tory ministers have set a ‘Way to Work’ target to help , Universal Credit claimants into work by June.But despite the PM’s boast, it’s thought the plan is only to get , people into jobs - not off Universal Credit. Sources told the Mirror some of those people are likely to continue claiming, at least in the short term, as around two-fths of UC claimants already have a job. They remain eligible for benefits because their wages are too low. Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves wrote a letter in April  ‘suggesting we could secure PPE supplies from a theatrical costumier and we could get ventilators from a professional football agentapos Ms Reeves did write a letter, and the firms it mentioned did include one behind ‘historic re-enactment clothing’ that was offering to make - gowns a week. However, the context is that she passed on the details of  firms that were offering to supply PPE - without actually endorsing their work.Instead her letter told Michael Gove : “You and your officials and those at the Department for Health and Social Care will be best placed to validate what capability and capacity these firms have.“But as they have not received a reply after contacting the Government, I wanted to ensure that the Cabinet Office was aware of them.” Labour insist she was simply raising concerns about the number of firms at the time that were not getting a response.  Keir Starmer ‘would have kept us in lockdown’While he didn’t specy this time, Boris Johnson has repeatedly made this claim in relation to December  when Omicron surged.The Labour leader welcomed additional measures to curb Omicron rates before Christmas  - but he had never called for a lockdown. At one point Mr Starmer said: Weaposve got a government that are hinting at further restrictions but theyaposre more concerned and tied up with party management at the moment than it is with public health. The question on my lips and I think on the publicaposs lips is where is the prime minister One time Keir Starmer definitely did demand a lockdown was in autumn  - and Boris Johnson eventually caved and obeyed those calls a few weeks later. ‘We’ve opened Freeports across the country just in the last few days’Eight successful bidders for Freeports were announced at the March  Budget.Since then they have been working up their plans. Teesside opened in November and Thames in mid-December. But when we asked the government today, we were told the other six are yet to open. Neither the Mirror nor officials we asked could find evidence of new Freeports opening in the last month or so. title: 8 things announced levelling up
story: things announced in Levelling Up Plan - and our verdict on what they meanMinisters said their levelling up plans will address schools, crime, transport as well as broadband. Here, we take a look at some of the governments promises - and what they really meanMichael Gove in Westminster today Image: Tayfun Salci ZUMA Press Wire REX ShutterstockByJason BeattieHead of politicsRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe governmentaposs levelling up plans have been slammed as devoid of new ideas. Ministers said the missions include “improving wellbeing in every area” of the UK, a devolution deal for every part of England that wants one, and bringing public transport connectivity across the country “signicantly closer to the standards of London”.Levelling-Up Secretary Michael Gove also raised the prospect of the House of Lords moving out of London. “I think it’d be a really good thingthe House of Lords were to meet for at least part of the time in Glasgow or in York,” he told Times Radio. But Labour said all of the pledges so far have been recycled pots of money and not what we were promised.Here, we look at some of the things announced by the government, and give our verdict on what they really mean.  Schools They say: “By , the number of primary schoolchildren achieving the expected standard in reading, writing and maths will have increased.”Our verdict: The government has set a new goal of ensuring that % of schoolchildren will have reached the national standard, but in , the figure was %.Ministers have identied  communities for intensive additional support and they are largely outside of London. Quite how “intensive” this support will be delivered is also not clear.  Housing What they are promising: Improve the quality of rented homes and bring in the National Landlord Register to aid tenants. The green belt will be protected and first-time buyers will increase.Verdict: Alicia Kennedy of the Generation Rent campaign group welcomed the National Landlord Register and pledge to end no-fault evictions.But there is no extra money to build more affordable housing. No is stoking the property market by helping people get a foot on the ladder rather than investing in social housing. Mayors What they say: “By , every part of England that wants one will have a devolution deal with powers at or approaching the highest level of devolution and a simplied, long-term funding settlement.”Our verdict: Critics have hit out at the Tories’ piecemeal approach to devolving power so far, with cities having more controls than neighbouring areas, as well as the benefit of mayors such as Andy Burnham acting as national champions. The fear now is that doing deals with each area in turn could achieve the opposite of an “end to the postcode lottery”. Health and wellbeing What they say: By , the gap in Healthy Le Expectancy between local areas where it is highest and lowest will have narrowed, and by  HLE will rise by five years.Our verdict: The latest ONS data showed that the UK overall had seen the first fall in le expectancy in  years. Researchers recently found a -year gap between the le expectancy of a man living in Kensington and Cha and Blackpool. The Health Foundation says the Government “faces a massive challenge”, with funds needed to tackle smoking, obesity and NHS improvement.Crime What they are promising: By  homicide, serious violence and neighbourhood crime will have fallen, focused on the worst-affected areas.There will be , more police officers on our streets by  and a £million Safer Streets Fund to improve the environment and cut offending in high-crime areas. Verdict: There is a question mark over whether these targets can be hit. Under the Tories police officers fell from , to ,.Despite a vow to recruit , more, there are now ,. In the year to March  there was a % rise in homicides and % rise in kne crime. Latest figures show fewer than one in  crimes are solved. Transport What they say: “By , local public transport connectivity across the country will be signicantly closer to the standards of London, with improved services, simpler fares and integrated ticketing.”Our verdict: Towns and cities outside of the capital require dferent transport solutions to the economic powerhouse that is the UK’s capital, with buses and creaking rail lines badly in need of investment.The Government says the plan will take in £.billion for city regions UK-wide and £bn for the integrated rail plan. But already, promises of £bn for bus services appear to be roughly half of the cash promised, with ministers to focus on “bus improvements in areas where this can make the most impact”. The £bn integrated rail plan, meanwhile, has been watered down with the key £bn plan for Leeds to Manchester to be delivered through upgrades on the existing transpennine track, rather than a new line through Bradford.  Sports and culture What they are promising: A £bn Culture Recovery Fund for museums, theatres, cinemas and heritage groups. More Arts Council cash to go outside London. Extra support for grassroots sports.Verdict: All of these measures have been previously announced. The Culture Recovery Fund was part of the pandemic package to help venues during lockdown.While more money from the Arts Council will go to regions, its budget has not been increased. The £m for new football pitches was unveiled last June. Broadband What they are promising: By , the UK will have nationwide gigabit-capable broadband and G coverage, with G coverage for most of the population.Verdict: Not only a re-announcement – it’s actually a delay. Ministers already said they were investing £billion in G coverage, aiming to have it across most of the UK by . Now it’s . news politics energy-price-cap-announcement-full-"Rachel Reeves reacts to Rishi Sunaks energy announcementByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb |commentsMillions of Brits are facing eye-watering rises in their energy bills this April - despite a big announcement of government support.The average household bill will go up by £ a year thanks to the biggest-ever rise in the energy price cap. It comes after the price of wholesale gas quadrupled over the last year, worsened by the threat of a Russian war in Ukraine. At the same time the Bank of England has raised interest rates to .% from .%, making mortgages more expensive.Chancellor Rishi Sunak today announced a three-pronged fightback with a £ Warm Home Discount, £ off bills and £ off council tax. He said: “Without government action this would be incredibly tough for millions of hard-working families. So the government is going to step in to directly help people manage those extra costs.”  But furious critics said it’s not enough. Dame Meg Hillier, chair of the Public Accounts Committee, declared: “We now have the Klarna Chancellor - get it now and pay later.” So what has been announced today and are you eligible  Here is the move explained.What is the rise in the energy price cap in April The average household’s energy bills will rise by £ a year from April , regulator Ofgem has confirmed. Those on default tarfs paying by direct debit will see an increase from £, to £, - or %. Prepayment customers, many on benefits, will be worse hit with an increase of £ from £, to £,. The move will affect  million households and follows a £-a-year rise only in October. It will affect default tarf customers who haven’t switched to a fixed deal and those who remain with their new supplier after their previous supplier exited the market. Those on fixed deals will continue to pay what they do now, but will see their rates soar by the time they move to a new fixed deal. What has Rishi Sunak announced today The Tory Chancellor announced a three-pronged approach to make up for about half of the energy bills hit coming in April. More or less all British households will get £ off their energy bills in October in a £.bn scheme, but then have to pay back this discount over five years. Around % of households in England on the lowest council tax bands will get a £ rebate in April, which won’t have to be paid back. And finally, a £-a-year Warm Home Discount will be extended to more people in England and Wales and raised by £ a year from October.Who is eligible for the £ off energy bills and how do I get it All domestic electricity customers - around million households - will receive a £ upfront discount on their bills. Energy suppliers will be loaned the money to do this by the government, and apply the discount “from October”, said the Treasury. Indications are that you won’t have to do anything to claim the discount and it will be applied to your bills automatically. But about % of pre-payment customers - who top up at the shop - will get something “more manual”, such as barcodes or QR codes through the post. Customers will then have to pay back the £ discount at a rate of £ per year out of their bills, in the five years from  to . Rishi Sunak said the £ discount will apply in England, Scotland and Wales. Northern Ireland will have the funds to choose to do the same thing. The full details of how it’ll be paid - and paid back - have not yet been worked out and the Business Department will run a consultation. Who is eligible for the £ off council tax and how do I get it All households in England that are in council tax bands A, B, C or D will get a £ rebate off their council tax bills for one year. The government says this covers around % of all the households in the country. The rebate will be made directly by councils in April, when they issue bills for the next year, as a one-off credit on your direct debit account. Some households do not pay by direct debit. The Treasury claimed councils “will be ready to process their claims in April”. Chancellor Rishi Sunak said it will not apply to second homes or empty homes. We are still waiting for more details. Unlike the £ discount on energy bills, the £ off council tax will not have to be paid back. This policy will only apply in England, but Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will receive funding to replicate the movethey wish to.You can check your council tax band here.Do I have to pay it back The £ discount off energy bills in October does have to be paid back, at a rate of £ per year for five years from . The £ rebate off council tax bills does not have to be paid back - but there is a sting in the tail. Council tax bills will still rise this year, at % for many authorities, and is likely to rise again in April . That meansthere’s no rebate next year, people will feel a big rise in their pockets all at once.What other help was announced today The Warm Home Discount Scheme will be raised by £ to £ in October, and eligibility will be extended to about , more households than now. That will expand the scheme to .million households in total on a permanent basis - but only from next winter. Currently you’re eligibleyou’re on a low income and meet a criteria from your supplier, or you get a Guarantee Credit element of Pension Credit. Under the expansion, more people will be assigned as being eligible for the discount by their supplier, which is done using a complicated formula. The Warm Home Discount Scheme applies to England and Wales. Meanwhile, there is help for some people who will slip through the cracks of the council tax discount announced today. The Treasury said there’ll be £m of discretionary funds for people who are vulnerable or on low incomes, that either do not pay Council Tax, or pay Council Tax for properties in Bands E-H. Does it go far enough  Furious critics, unions and Labour say it does not.It only funds half the rise in energy bills, £ of the £ has to be paid back, and it ignores all the other rises heading down the track in April. National Insurance is rising, inflation is sending prices in shops soaring, and student loan repayment thresholds and tax thresholds are being frozen. Labour MP Chris Bryant branded it “puny” saying: “£ isn’t going to touch the sides for my constituents in the Rhondda. “Gas and electricity up for the average family in my constituency by £. Fuel up by £. The average weekly shop up by £.“ Universal Credit cut by £,. National Insurance up by £. And frozen tax allowances by him will cost another £. That’s £, in a constituency where the average wage is £,. That is really going to cause hardship. £ doesn’t even touch it.” What were the other suggestions Rishi Sunak rejected Labour had called for the % VAT rate to be cut on energy bills, but Rishi Sunak said this would “disproportionately benefit wealthier households”. “There would be no guarantee suppliers would pass on the discount to customers,” he said, “and this would become a permanent government subsidy on people’s bills.” Others, including the Resolution Foundation and Labour MP Stephen Timms, raised the idea of raising benefits to target the poorest instead of the chosen plan.Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves slammed the use of council tax - as some rich people live in Band D homes while poorer bigger families can live in Band E, partly because bandings are outdated.She said: “That will mean many of the poorest households will not get extra support while some of the richest do. And it’s people living in the north and the Midlands who’ll lose out most. “The hypocrisy, the day after the government’s Levelling Up White Paper, is obvious.” Rishi Sunak defended his decision not to only announce temporary help for families - much of which will have to be paid back out of future bills. He said: “It is not sustainable to keep holding the price of energy articially low. “For me to stand here and pretend we don’t have to adjust to paying higher prices would be wrong and dishonest. “But what we can do is take the sting out of a signicant price shock for millions of families by making sure the increase in prices is smaller initially, and spread over a longer period.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TaxCouncil taxEnergy billsInterest ratesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: the tory party is over
story: What the Tories think of Boris Johnson is irrelevant. The PM will soon be out on his earThe Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds about whether this is survivable, says Fleet Street Fox. It isnt Image: Getty ImagesopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsWell. The Prime Minister is under direct criminal investigation. The evidence of his alleged crimes are being kept hidden from him for fear of interference.And with war brewing on Europeaposs eastern flank, the PM told the enemy he didnapost have time to ring, because he had too much arse-covering to do.The Conservative Party is like an abused we with no other home to go to, and in two minds, not about whether this is acceptable, but whether itaposs survivable. And like every victim, it has yet to realisethataposs the question, then itaposs time to go.  Yesterday, a report he resisted ordering was not published. Instead, there was an aposupdateapos on the alleged criminality of his office, his staff, and his personal residence, and the PM greeted it in the same way he has every Mirror front page, ITV broadcast, and BBC breaking news update since late November: a burst of surprise and contrition with a half-le of . seconds, decaying into toxic belligerence that will linger in the bone for a thousand years. Events for which there was not enough evidence to merit an investigation by the politan Police had, in the space of a month, uncovered  witnesses,  photographs, and  pieces of paper.Despite the insufficient evidence,  out of  parties, on  dates, have met the evidential threshold for an investigation, on the grounds that those involved knew they were against the rules, there was no reasonable justication for them, and not looking into it would end Cressida Dickaposs career quicker than sending the riot squad into a candlelit vigil.One of them is an alleged gathering in the Downing Street flat on November , , which Mrs Johnsonaposs personal spokeswoman has repeatedly insisted is total nonsense, but about which there seems to be enough evidence to merit weeks of attention by an entire squad of coppers.  While the -page report has been subbed down to just , it contains all the facts needed to decide the PMaposs future. Extensive, substantive, factual information is now available, wrote Sue Gray. There were failures of leadership and judgement. There was excessive consumption of alcohol. There was no way for those working in government to stop it breaking the law. There was a serious failure to observe, not just the standards expected of those working at the heart of government, but also of the standards expected of the entire British population at the time.The killer line is in paragraph . The excuse of long hours worked in the pandemic, in a building that could not be entirely Covid-secure, was destroyed. Those challenges... also applied to key and frontline workers across the country who were working under equally,not more, demanding conditions, often at risk to their own health... criminal sanctions were applied to many... the hardship under which citizens across the country worked, lived and sadly even died while observing the Governmentaposs regulations and guidance are known only too well. Every citizen has been impacted by the pandemic. One of them is Leshie Chandrapala. Her dad drove a bus. He died of Covid, and Leshie was not allowed to be with him as he lay in a coma in ICU. She believes he died because he didnapost get PPE at work, but the government hasnapost even written a letter of condolence to her family. A fortnight after he died, and while she grieved, they threw the BYO booze Downing Street garden party. The PMaposs response to the report was to say sorry for the way itaposs been handled, not sorry for doing it. And he has a solution. I know what the issue is, he declared. I get it, and I will fix it! He says he is taking personal charge, and setting up the Office of the Prime Minister. So who was in charge of his office for the past three years  Where is the drunken boozehound who careered around Downing Street Friday night drinkathons, encouraging staffers to let off steam with a long chug on the vodka bottle  Who allowed the culture of recklessness and lawlessness, at the heart of a government that was criminalising the same sins in others  Which leader has led his party to a disgrace worse than Windrush or Grenfell or Orgreave Bring me his head! bellows Boris from the Despatch Box. I will slay this beast, the same way that I would have slain Jimmy Savile,only I didnapost think that investigating historical sex abuse was money spaffed up the wall!Other things he has taken personal control of include Brexit, social care, test and trace, the energy crisis, the ministerial code of conduct, the saving of Owen Paterson, and funding for his gold wallpaper. The fact he took personal control of the vaccines may have something to do with the fact that  million people donapost want them. How many times has he taken charge, only for things to spin out of control  How many times has he shaken up the civil service, only to be rattled himself  Read more The nation is now watching the Conservative Party the same way as the rest of the street watches a victim get out of the police car, andto their abuser. They drag with them a whole country into this deranged, gnarled, unhappy misgovernment, back to the man who wonapost promise to publish the full truth in the House of Commons, where he might be held in contempthe failed to, but will promise it in the bar, to the MPs he has lied to for years, and who have been brainwashed into thinking such a promise is a concession rather than a repetition.Meanwhile the PM only appears in public when the public can be kept away from him. Abba tribute bands are raising their prices for satin satire. Andyou want a three-word slogan to describe where we are, it is simply: another fine mess. The PM or his we may get a fixed penalty notice pictures may or may not emerge. He may be out on his ear, or he may convince enough MPs to give him one more go. Itaposs irrelevant, because the fallout of this radioactive scandal will last to the ballot box and beyond it reaches into homes and hearts, to the guts and spines of millions to whom the words aposToryapos and aposPartyapos are now as repugnant as the fact that people like Leshie had their pain doubled and then dismissed by a man whose charm has long since been spent. The Tories got drunk on power, picked a man who can be fooled by a cake, and then dithered about whether to let him keep hurting the rest of us. They cannot see what the rest of us can: their party is over. story: Bamboo plant causes devastating £, damage to horried neighbours homeBamboo planted at a Hampshire home somehow grew under the neighbours property and broke through its concrete floor - causing a huge £, worth of damageThe only way to solve the problem was to dig up the ground floor of the Hampshire house Image: Environet UKByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsHomeowners have been issued an urgent warning after a home faced £, worth of damage caused by a running bamboo plant.Bamboo was planted at the property to form some of the border hedge, but allegedly it was left unmonitored and grew as a result.The plantaposs roots grew underneath the next door home and broke through its concrete floor. It then continued to grow through the propertyaposs cavity walls and eventually it would have forced the walls apartit hadnapost been tackled. The only way to solve the problem was to dig up the ground floor of the Hampshire house and remove hundreds of metres of bamboo rhizomes. The home insurance claim for the damage was apparently more than £,, reports the Express.Japanese Knotweed is famously a nightmare, but experts have said bamboo can be just as baditaposs left to grow unmonitored. The roots of bamboo can travel up to a whopping  metres and they can break through all sorts of surfaces, from bricks and drains to cavity walls and patios.  aposRunningapos ieties of bamboo like the one found at the Hampshire property are particularly prolic as they send lateral shoots out underneath the ground which can sometimes pop up on neighboursapos plots. Founder and MD of Environet UK, Nic Seal, told the Sun: Through no fault of their own, the homeowners have suffered signicant financial cost, stress and inconvenience, being required to vacate their home for several months. The truth is, most bamboos are invasiveplanted directly into the ground and left to their own devices. He added that the Hampshire case was the worst case of bamboo encroachment heaposd ever seen in this country. Experts advise itaposs best to choose a clumping iety of bamboo rather than a running iety to avoid spreading problems like these. Those buying bamboo should also plant it in a pot instead of in the ground and make sure to trim it frequently. title: catcalling unacceptable needs taken seriously
story: Catcalling is unacceptable - it needs to be taken seriously once and for allBradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcallingImage: Getty Images AlloyopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Feb |commentsIt probably seems like a small thing, at best. At worst, a waste of time and resources. It’s not though. It’s important. A tiny triumph. A baby step in the right direction. Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – “targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.” Last week they stopped a van after the occupant yelled at some women who turned out to be plain-clothed police officers. Oh to have seen his face. He was reported for a breach of the Public Spaces Protection Order and is likely to be issued with a £ fine or taken to court, which is another way of saying that he was left in no doubt that THIS IS NOT OK. That’s apparently what men need to be told, reminded of, in no uncertain terms, so they’re one hundred per cent clear. No, it’s not just a bit of harmless fun that we need to lighten up about. It’s horrendous. Scary. Humiliating.  Maybe this concept is confusing because we’re living in an age of sharing, honesty, and talking about everything. Mostly that’s great, but somewhere within this, a simple truth has got lost. Sometimes, it’s good NOT to talk. Sometimes, you need to shut the hell up. Perhaps we need a massive advertising campaign, public service announcement telly commercials and posters everywhere to clearly inform everyone once and for all: Stop telling women what you think of their bodies. Especially when they haven’t asked, which is pretty much always. There are no Thought Police – anyone is free to think whatever they like. The opinions inside someone’s head can’t hurt anyone . The problem comes when they’re broadcast out loud to the woman you’re thinking them about, be it on the street, online, or on a radio show, like that fool who talked about Strictly’s Tilly Ramsay. What you think of the woman’s body is irrelevant, by the way. Evenyou believe it’s a compliment, still keep it to yourself. Of course there are exceptions to the rule, but most women do not feel flattered and delighted when a stranger gives them positive feedback about a body part. We feel embarrassed, and frightened. And we’re taught to ignore this behaviour – apart from in Bradford, it’s up to us to deal with it ourselves – to put our heads down, walk quicker, in case the situation escalates.We’re luckywe are only verbally harassed. Even online, where the threat of physical violence is removed, these kind of comments are dangerous, and unacceptable. They perpetuate the belief that women’s appearances are fair game for discussion and debate. That our bodies are anyone’s business but our own. They also ensure that the practice of speaking about women in this way seeps down to future generations, continuing the cycle. It has to stop. As the fight to make our streets safer for women goes on, catcalling being taken seriously in one city in the UK is just a drop in the ocean. But at least it’s a start. Maybe those TV ads aren’t a bad idea – and it’s obvious what music they should be set to. Ronan Keating, You Say It Best, When You Say Nothing At All.
