title: couple lose 50000 after cowboy
story: Couple lose £, after cowboy builder walks off saying he doesnt need the stressJames Bradshaw said his family were left living on a building site in Wolverhampton after their builder walked off the job and a survey later showed all his work needed to be demolishedThe house was left with a half-finished extension after the builder walked off the job, saying he didnt need the stress Image: Kennedy News and MediaByRebecca CooleyJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A devastated couple say they have lost their £, le savings and been left living on a building site thanks to a cowboy builderaposs half-finished extension which then had to be demolished. James Bradshaw, , says the builder, who heaposd hired to add a two-storey extension to their house, would only work five-hour days and when confronted about his shoddy workmanship brazenly quit saying he didnapost want the stress .The couple agreed to pay almost £, to the builder, who came recommended by a family friend, for an extension to accommodate their growing family, a job that was supposed to be completed by August . But after months of issues and delays the builder vanished in September, leaving James and his family £, out of pocket and living on a building site. The -year-old says he has since had a surveyor assess the work that had been done, who concluded that it needed to be completely demolished and restarted due to structural issues. When James contacted a solicitor he was advised not to bother taking the builder to court as he wonapost see a penny of his hard-earned savings again - evenhe wins the case.  The sales director has now shared photos of the mess heaposs been left with in a bid to warn other conscientious and decent peopleapos not to fall victim to cowboy builders. James, from Wolverhampton, said: The reason we were having the extension done is because weaposve had a daughter and we have three children living with us already - my son and my fianceaposs two children. We were having the extension done to create two extra bedrooms and to extend the kitchen and dining room to have a bit more space for the kids. It was shocking from day one. He never did a full week, heaposd only turn up two to three times a weekat all and heaposd turn up at :am and leave at pm. Every time the building inspector came to review the work heaposd done it kept getting failed so he had to redo lots of it. Eventually I said to him aposyou need to come in for a meeting because this just isnapost good enoughapos. As he walked through the door he said aposIaposm going to give you your money back and you can get someone  to complete it because I canapost get it done and I donapost want the stress anymoreapos. He only offered us £, back and I just said aposyouaposre a joke and youaposll be hearing from our solicitoraposs. He left our house in the state itaposs in and we havenapost spoken to him since. Itaposs been a nightmare. Itaposs put a lot of strain on mine and my partneraposs le and caused a lot of devastation for our family. Weaposd been saving the money for about  years and weaposd got a loan to help as well which weaposre still paying back at the minute.  The two-storey extension was supposed to create two extra bedrooms and an extended kitchen and dining area within  weeks, for an agreed cost of £,. By the time of their final meeting in September - two months after the extension was supposed to be finished - there was only an incomplete single-storey and a plank of wood blocking where the back door used to be. The following month, an independent building survey confirmed that what was built was plagued with structural issues and needed to be completely demolished and restarted, despite the parents already forking out a whopping £,. The report found that the walls were out of square in numerous places and either had a cavity that was too wide or cavity ties that were too short. This means they werenapost fully tied in and didnapost provide full stability. It also noted that the entire structure was at risk of damp due to multiple issues, including mortar breaching the wall cavities, and aposlazy workmanshipapos was evident in the internal brickwork, where a broken brick aposlooked to have been jammed in placeapos. Overall the report concluded: Considering the overall condition of the build we would recommend that it is removed down to foundation level and the structure started again. Demolishing the work alone would cost an additional £. In light of this, James sought legal advice to try and claw back some of his hard-earned savings back to be able to recty the nightmare build.  But the dad says that his solicitor then delivered the devastating news that although he would definitely win in court he would never see a penny of the £, again because the builder could simply close the business down due to not having the funds to repay it. James said: I had a meeting with the solicitor and said aposdonapost tell me what I want to hear, tell me the honest truthapos. Her words were aposthe only person that wins in this is the solicitors because we get paid either way, itaposs going to cost you £, to £, to go to courtapos. She said aposyou will win in court but his solicitor will advise him to shut the company down because he hasnapost got the money to pay it back so you wonapost see a pennyapos.Two days after we received the court letter it came up on Facebook that the company was closed so I think heaposs already shut it down. Weaposve looked into his history a bit now as well and heaposs well known for opening companies and shutting them down - I think this is the fourth company heaposs done that with since . The family had new builders start at their home last week to demolish the unstable structure and restart the extension. But at a new estimated cost of £,, they can no longer afford to get much of the project done. The heartbroken dad hopes that by warning people about the dishonest and unreliable cowboy he fell victim to, he can help other families avoid the same fate. James said: Thereaposs nothing we can do now, we just have to bite the bullet that weaposre not going to get anything from it because the system doesnapost support this kind of thing. Weaposve got new builders in now but because weaposve wasted so much money we can only afford to get the shell done and weaposll have to do the inside stage by stage. The new quote to put right and finish it is £, because thereaposs been a huge increase in prices of building materials and labour as well as the extra work of demolishing it. story: Covid cases now almost at , a day with infections increasing, new data suggestsThe ZOE study data estimates that the current R value is at . for England, Scotland and Wales. It also shows that in England  in  have Covid, with  in  in Wales and  in  in ScotlandProfessor Tim Spector leads the ZOE study Image: Ken McKay ITV REX ShutterstockByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsCovid cases across the UK have increased by  per cent since last week and are at almost ,, data from the ZOE study has revealed.The figures, which are based on both PCR and LFT test data, also estimates that the current R value is at . for England, Scotland and Wales. There are currently , new daily symptomatic coronavirus cases in the UK on average, based on test data from up to three days ago, which is an increase of  per cent from , reported last week. Of those, those who were vaccinated with at least two doses made up , of the new daily symptomatic cases in the UK, up from , new daily cases last week.The study also shows that in England  in  have covid, with  in  in Wales and  in  in Scotland.  It also reveals that cases are now rising in all age groups, but the rise is much smaller in the + age groups, particularly in the older, more vulnerable + group, the increase is very small. According to the data, ZOE estimates that  per cent of people experiencing new “cold-like“ symptoms are likely to have symptomatic Covid.Professor Tim Spector, lead scientist on the ZOE COVID Study app, said: “While the bad news is we are again approaching , new cases a day, it’s encouraging that recorded hospitalisations, ICU cases and deaths are still coming down as Omicron is less severe in a vaccinated population.With a lag of several weeks between infections and hospitalisations, we’ll continue to monitor this rate closely in the coming weeks. We saw a similar rebound and second peak during the Delta wave as people relaxed more and children went back to school. It seems many are, again, preempting the end of the Covid- pandemic.It’s much too early for this.High case rates will likely be with us until late spring before the warmer weather and the summer holidays help reduce infections again.He addd: Over the past few weeks, the UK governmentaposs confirmed cases data has begun to move further away from ZOE’s findings. There are a number of reasons for this. The biggest factor is the change in testing behaviour that has happened this year. ZOE Contributors are now logging more positive LFTs in the app, and fewer PCRs. LFTs no longer have to be confirmed by a PCR so are often not being logged with the government, so confirmed case data is missing thousands of LFT results, leading to massive under-reporting. This subtle but important change in behaviour, highlights the importance of having multiple methods to track COVID in the population and shows the power of the citizen scientists that log with ZOE every day. title: cruel neglectful pandemic puppy farmer
story: Cruel, neglectful pandemic puppy farmer jailed after breaking lelong dog banJeremy Awdry was sentenced to  weeks imprisonment after he admitted breaches of the dog ban, just months after it was imposedAwdry kept the puppies in squalid conditions at his home Image: Gloucestershire News ServiceByMirror:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A -year-old puppy farmer branded “cruel” and “neglectful” when he was convicted in court last year and disqualied from keeping dogs for le has been jailed for flouting the ban.Jeremy Awdry, of Bream, Gloucestershire - a sheep owner with commoners rights in the Forest of Dean - was sentenced yesterday to  weeks imprisonment after he admitted breaches of the dog ban, just months after it was imposed. Prosecutor Sara Anthony told Cheltenham Magistrates Court that a year ago Awdry was disqualied for le from owning, keeping, transporting or being in any way involved with dogs. The ban was imposed in February  at Gloucester Crown Court after Awdry and two other defendants were convicted for selling puppies without a licence, and failing to meet the needs of the animals. The puppies were kept in squalid conditions at Awdryaposs home and were poorly looked after. Awdry and his two accomplices were estimated to have made £, from puppy farming over four years. Yesterday, Ms Anthony told the court that the Forest of Dean District Council was tipped off that Awdry was still using dogs for work and had been seen transporting his dogs about, shortly after his dog ban was imposed. On April ,  at .am two members of the councilaposs street warden team were in the Bream area and were travelling along Oakwood Road when they spotted Awdry in a white Nissan vehicle beside a five bar gate,” Ms Anthony said. “They both had a clear view of a black and white Collie sitting on the front passenger seat. They watched Awdry turn the vehicle around and drive to the other side of the field and park alongside an outbuilding. They both saw Awdry unload two Collie dogs from the vehicle and usher them towards the outbuilding. Awdry was then observed ing to his vehicle without the dogs. Awdry drove down Highfield Close and disappeared from the area. The street wardens checked the outbuilding and observed that the two dogs were inside. While the wardens were making notes of what they had just witnessed Awdry ed in his van accompanied by his we. He parked beside the outbuilding and opened the door while Mrs Awdry encouraged the dogs into the vehicle from the passenger side. Awdry ed to the vehicle and drove off. On the second occasion the district council was contacted by PC Katherine McDay who was driving in a marked vehicle from Coleford to Bream on May  last year at around pm when she noticed Awdryaposs Nissan van on the B near the area of Bream Cross. She noticed a large amount of sheep coming from a field opposite. Pc McDay travelled past the Nissan and turned around. While she travelled back towards the van she noticed that Awdry was driving and his we was in the passenger seat with a black Collie dog on her lap. As Pc McDay passed she noticed that the dog was released out of the passenger door and it began herding sheep along the road. A short while later she noticed Awdry drive away from the area and saw that the sheep were no longer visible. The dog had its head out of the passenger window. Clive Rees, defending, said: I feel that Awdry did not fully understand the rules surrounding the disqualication order. He was under the impression thathe had somebody with him who was responsible for the dogs he would be complying with the terms of the order. Awdry had already transferred ownership of the dogs to his we. He has kept dogs all his le and, being a commoner, he has the right to roam sheep on the common. He frequently gets calls from police to remove them from the road, eventhey are not his own sheep. When the order was initially issued Awdry would get his we to drive his van with the dogs. However over the past few months Mrs Awdryaposs health has deteriorated and she has recently lost much of her eyesight and most of her hearing. Mr Awdry has become her carer. Awdry started the order with good intentions. His son has now taken over the responsibility for the dogs. Whoever saw the dogs, there was no mention of them being concerned about the animalsapos welfare. In the future Awdry will have to come to terms about not looking after sheep in future. He realises now that he is in a serious position. He should have known the position when he was sentenced at Gloucester Crown Court. Awdry pleaded guilty to breaching a disqualication order imposed after conviction on two occasions. On or around April ,  at Lydney, having been previously disqualied from keeping dogs he transported two black and white collie dogs inside a white Nissan white van, and on May ,  he transported a black and white collie dog inside the same van whilst directing  sheep to exit a field and move along the B Rd heading towards Bream. Presiding Justice Major Paul Adey sentenced Awdry to six weeks imprisonment for the two offences of transporting dogs and activated the  week suspended sentence consecutively. We note that the dogs are no longer in your and Mrs Awdryaposs ownership, a move which should have been undertaken  months ago, said the magistrate. “We also acknowledge that the dogs have not been mistreated whilst they have been in your care. The justices ordered that outstanding court costs of £, and the £, costs of yesterdayaposs case must be paid by Awdry by th April this year. After yesterdayaposs hearing Forest of Dean District Councilaposs Animal Welfare Member Champion, Councillor Nicky Packer said Our Street Warden team do a fantastic job year round of ensuring that animals in our district are looked after properly, and that those who mistreat or cause harm to their animals are held accountable.” This verdict should stand as testament to this. A ban on keeping dogs means exactly that. If, as in this case, it isnapost followed, our Street Warden and Counter Fraud and Enforcement team will enforce it. A council spokesperson added The prosecution was undertaken by Forest of Dean District Councilaposs Legal Services team working with the Councilaposs Street Wardens Team and Counter Fraud and Enforcement Unit . Tuesday night.Fty firefighters battled to control the inferno, but they were unable to save the schoolaposs roof, Yorkshire Live reported. A -year-old man, who was found at the scene by officers, remains in custody after being arrested on suspicion of arson. The man was also taken to hospital for treatment on Tuesday. Gazing upon the destruction on Wednesday, parents whose children currently attend the school and former pupils spoke of how the fire has devastated a whole community. Ex-pupil Valerija Balinskaite, , said she broke down after hearing the news.  I was in tears, she said. It was awful. I live just a five minutesapos walk from the school. I saw a video of the fire and it just broke me. I have so many happy memories from the school. Grace Berry, whose seven-year-old daughter attends the school, said: It is just devastating for the community. It is devastating for the kids and teachers to wake up to these circumstances. But it is a strong community and I am sure it will pull together and pull through - these things tend to bring people together. Derek Barlow said the school is widely considered as iconic in the local area, and many of the people living nearby graced its hallways when they were younger. My we went there and I have had two children who have been to this school, he said. It was a bit gut-wrenching watching it last night. My we was sending me photos of it . She was very upset about it and the community is very upset about it, actually. The community is absolutely devastated about it - this school is iconic.  Headteacher Mr Mungo Sheppard said that emergency services had managed to save quite a bit of the building. I have no idea how quickly we can get back in, he continued. Mr Sheppard added that some children may have to be educated at other sites while repair work takes place at the school. story: Inside abandoned RAF base which played crucial role fighting Nazis during WWRAF Church Fenton in North Yorkshire was used by British pilots to defend some of Englands biggest cities from German bombers in the early stages of WWInside the abandoned RAF base once used to defend Britain against the Nazis Image: Jam Press Bearded RealityByRuby PensonLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments An abandoned RAF base has been left to rot after its crucial role in WW when it was used to defend Britain from the Nazis.Eerie photos show rotting walls, crumbling floors and vandalism throughout RAF Church Fenton in Tadcaster, North Yorkshire. Fearless pilots once used the base, which was built in , to help defend some of the biggest cities in England during the war.Some of the site continued to be used decades after the fighting but much of it has been left to decay for years, reports Yorkshire Live.During WWII, the airfield was home to ious aircraft from Hurricanes, Mosquitoes, Blenheims and Beaufighters to Typhoons and Mustangs. It also housed a fast but flimsy wooden aircraft called the de Havilland Mosquito which was only in service for a matter of months before being disused.  The base was tasked with defending some of the great industrial cities of northern England from German bombers at the beginning of the war. Some of Britainaposs very first night fighters flew out of the Yorkshire base with some paying the ultimate price to protect the nation. The site also hosted a signicant amount of squadrons including the firstRAF aposEagleapos Squadron of American volunteers, the first all-Canadian RAF Squadron, and the first all-Polish RAF Squadron.  Photographer Bearded Reality captured a series of pictures which show what is left of the base some eight decades later. The images offer an insight into what le would have been like for those who spent time there over the years. In a YouTube video, he shows some of the rooms that were covered in graffiti and taken over by nature including an old bar and kitchen area.  Debris hung from the ceilings while some of the flooring has collapsed. After the war ended, RAF Church Fenton was used as a frontline fighter station in the defence of northern England to the late s. Since then it has been falling apart and simply left to the elements. Initially, the station continued to be used after the war and its role changed to pilot training by .  But it was finally shut down for good in  by which time a number of its buildings had already fallen into disuse. The video shows Daniel and his companions running at dferent points after hearing other people in the building. At the end of the video, Daniel tells viewers: “That was RAF Fenton, AKA Leeds East Airport. Unfortunately, we couldn’t get into the tower because security rolled up right beside us. “The place is creepy but an amazing explore.”  After posting the video on YouTube, some viewers asked Daniel for more information about the site but he told them the buildings he visited were now gone. story: Exclusive: Ive had no heating for month as cant afford bills and food - I share bed with kids to stay warmMum-of-two Beth Connock, who is a full-time carer for her disabled son, has to share a bed with her children to keep them warm after a hike in the price of oil left them without heatingThe family have been left without heating for a month Image: Beth ConnockByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb |commentsSingle mum Beth Connock can no longer afford to keep the house warm AND feed her two children after her heating bills soared by  per cent. The -year-old mum of two - who is a full-time carer to disabled son Tommy, aged  - has now lived without heating for more than a month.“Itaposs really upsetting because I feel like a failure of a mother. I can choose between keeping my house warm at the moment and feeding the kids. “And the kids need to be fed but they need to be warm, it’s quite upsetting. No one should have to choose between feeding or eating.” Beth is one of the . million UK householders whose heating is powered by oil as her home in the rural hamlet of Dartshill, Somerset does not have a mains gas supply.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Her problem started as the cost to heat her family home, which she rents, rose sharply - from £ to £ for  litres, to fill less than half the tank.The cost of living crisis has left the mum, Tommy, five, and Gabby, three, forced to share a bed each night.They have a tiny electric heater to warm the bedroom they share, but in the evenings, they can see their breath in their living room when the temperature drops. Desperate to keep her children warm, Beth bundles them up in jumpers and scarves at home - but Tommy, who is autistic, struggles to wear the outfits. She says: “We’re wearing a lot of extra layers and having to sleep in the same bed to keep warm. “I shut the bedroom door to keep our body heat in but as soon as we got downstairs, it is freezing and we’re all shivering. “It’s a very old draughty cottage, I woke up the other morning around  am to find ice around the windowsill. “We’re wearing a lot more clothes, which means a lot more washing and a backlog of clothes as we wait days for things to dry. “It’s also a choice when it comes to hot water -the kids have a bath, I can’t have a shower as well.” She added: “I have no money and I’m worried about the kids getting ill because it is so cold. “February and March can be the coldest months so I needed to get something done quickly.” Tommy, aged five, is “very delayed” and has to wear specic clothes, meaning he doesn’t like wearing the extra layers.Beth is unable to work after becoming his full-time carer due to his severe epilepsy and the family rely on Universal Credit to get by.She previously tried to get a loan but was refused as she still owes around £ from the last loan she received. “I’ve tried everything. I even tried to get a grant in my local area but I heard nothing back,” the mum said. She also claims disability allowance to support him, who spent nine weeks in hospital in , suffering constant seizures. He has to wear a helmet to protect himselfhe falls, and mum Beth is on constant alert for his seizures. “Because of his epilepsy and autism, he is very delayed, and he doesn’t understand why we need to wear these extra clothes,” added Beth. “So trying to keep him warm it’s really dficult, he’s used to having heating and now we don’t have it. “It’s very frustrating for him.”  The desperate mum recently turned toGoFundMeto help cover the £ bill - where one kindhearted stranger donated £ anonymously.The hike in the price of oil comes amid a cost of living crisis with Beth’s rent recently rising by £ per month - a rise she will struggle to cover. Struggling Brits are bracing for further financial turmoil this spring - with tax rises, wage cuts and soaring bills set to batter household budgets further.The cost of living crisis could see families suffer a £, a year average hit, The Mirror exclusively revealed today - in a further blow to families such as Bethaposs.Low-income families are set to be the most affected by the crisis - with no spending they can cut back on. She said: “We scrape by every month, it’s dficult. With Universal Credit, I don’t knowthey’ll cover the rent increase. “As a single mum on benefits, £ is a lot of money. “Tommy’s school is about half an hour away so I do an hour-round journey every day to get him there. “It got to the point where I was desperate for heating and I just had to set up a GoFundMe page.” She plans to donate any excess to the Daisy Garland charity, that supported her family while Tommy was in the hospital.Donate to Beth’sGoFundMehere.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsOil pricesSingle mumEpilepsyAsperger’s syndromeEnergy bills" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man given days live after
story: Man given days to live after blood cancer symptoms dismissed as old age for  yearsRetired bus driver Brian Mellor, , from Blackpool, was found unable to move last year after bending down to wash his hands - he has since been diagnosed with cancerBrians cancer went undiagnosed for  years as doctors put symptoms down to old ageByRebecca LockwoodLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A retired bus driver nearly died after his incurable blood cancer went undiagnosed for  years after his symptoms were put down to old age.Brian Mellor, , from Blackpool, couldnapost move after his femur and hip had split open for no logical reason.Brianaposs daughter, Alyson Yates, , and husband Alan are planning weekly gigs throughout March to raise money for Myeloma UK which funds research into a cure which almost claimed her fatheraposs le last year, reports Lancashire Live.Doctors had reportedly dismissed Brianaposs previous symptoms, aches and pains as old age. Tests continued tonegative and the family felt nobody could explain what was wrong with him. Brian was found aposunable to moveapos on May  last year after bending down to wash his hands. Little did we know that our world was about to be blown apart, Alyson said. My dad suddenly was unable to move and we had to call an ambulance. It came to light that my dadaposs femur and hip had split open but there was no logical reason for this he hadnapost banged himself or had a fall. On the May  after much investigation it came to light that my dad had myeloma and was very poorly. He wasnapost even awake so I couldn’t tell him how much I loved him and that he had to fight. The next day, Alyson said she had to discuss a do-not-resuscitate order with her fatheraposs consultant. What a shocker, she said, we only found out about the cancer the day before and he only came into hospital  days before that. How can things be this bad so quick  May  was one of the worst days of our le, Alyson continued. We got a call to say come in, Dad wasnapost going to be pulling through, and would not make the weekend. To this point we had all been restricted to seeing my dad because of Covid but now we were allowed to be by his side. I cannot emphasise what a shock this week had been to us all. How quick the tide had turned in our le. What I can tell you is from my own point of view the heart-breaking pain I felt, Iaposd never felt pain like it and it was like I could not breathe and my world had crashed into a million pieces.  Sadly, a lot of families go through this journey leading to their diagnosis. Another reason why knowledge, awareness, training and earlier diagnosis is so important. Myeloma is an incurable blood cancer that occurs in the bone marrow. It currently affects more than , people in the UK. On average,  people are diagnosed with Myeloma every day in the UK. Alyson said: My dad had fallen sick in October  and despite many tests ran nothing came to light. Even a few weeks before May st, Dad had more tests done and still nothing had shown up, even in the blood tests for cancer. Going back through my dadaposs medical history it is now thought that his myeloma could go back  years when it was at the apossmoulderingapos stage but right up to him being hospitalised nothing ever came to light. The myeloma had remained undetected. Another reason why a better diagnosis system needs to be found. Despite being told he had just days to live, Brian went home in July - a day that Alyson says is one they never thought we would see. Brian is said to have responded well to chemotherapy - but the damage done to his body cannot be reversed. He is on chemotherapy every day to give him some extra time. Another dficult side to Myeloma is that it does y from person to person and besides the cancer, myeloma can come with many other complications. For my dad it is his heart and lungs. Now Alyson and husband Alan, who run Alan Yates Music, are planning to do weekly gigs throughout March this year in a bid to fund the research into a cure for Myeloma.Alyson is immunocompromised, meaning her immune system is extremely weak and she is at higher risk of contracting Covid-.Myeloma may become curable but funds are required for that and funds are required to help those in today’s society where there isnapost a cure, she said. She said she wanted to support Myeloma UK to help fund research into a cure and to raise awareness of Myeloma so “it doesn’t happen to anybody . We went through a horrendous journey as a family and the thought of another family going through that… I just can’t”. Myeloma UK is the only organisation in the UK exclusively dedicated to Myeloma and its related conditions. They rely almost entirely on voluntary donations and fundraising. Their ultimate goal is to find a cure for Myeloma and until then aim to help every patient live well with the diagnosis for as long as possible.To find out more about myeloma and the work of Myeloma UK click here. story: Mum livid as frightened girl, , abandoned in dark by bus driver due to faulty machineDaiva Paskeviciene, from Edinburgh, said that her daughter was twice denied on board buses due to a problem with her pass and is now scared to use public transportA mum was left fuming after her daughter was twice denied on buses Image: edinburghliveByIona YoungTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA furious mum has told how her frightened -year-old daughter was left in the dark and cold after a bus driver wouldnapost allow her on board due to a faulty ticket machine. Daiva Paskeviciene, from Edinburgh,said that her daughter, a pupil at Tollcross Primary School, was not allowed on the bus because her pass did not work, and claimed it was a fault with the machine.The first alleged incident happened on January  when the schools had just gone back after Christmas break, reported EdinburghLive.Ms Paskeviciene said she received a call from her terried daughter after she was left alone waiting in the cold for  minutes for another bus home. The -year-old is claimed to have presented her junior ridacard, that had been topped up that morning, to the machine on the bus. The driver told her it wasnapost working so she could not get on and would have to leave the bus. Ms Paskeviciene told EdinburghLive: My daughter is in P at Tollcross and is -years-old, it happened after Christmas when schools went back. Usually she gets the bus, on that day at around .pm. She went to the bus with her bus card that I topped up that morning. The machine wasnapost working so the driver told her she couldnapost get on the bus. He then got angry and was shouting at her. She got really scared. The bus stop was at Lothian Road, she had to wait  minutes for the next one it got dark and very cold. She called me and eventually a stranger had to give her money to be able to get home. Next time I made sure she had spare change just in case.  I couldnapost believe a driver would act like that to a little girl then it happened again. She got a new bus card the free Young Scot one, it worked in the morning on the bus but again when she was trying to get on the  after school, she tapped her card and it didnapost work. The driver said, aposyour card doesnapost work, you arenapost coming onapos my daughter called me crying, and is now afraid to catch the bus to school. A spokesman for Lothian Buses said: Lothian is committed to delivering safe, reliable public transport for all of our customers. We would always ask that our customers contact our customer services teamthey have concerns regarding their travel experience and would encourage this customer to contact us directly with more information to allow us to investigate the matter. title: nestle shutting down uk factory
story: Nestle shutting down UK factory with Brit favourites set to be made in Eastern EuropeProduction of popular items such as Fruit Pastilles, Toffee Crisps and mini eggs will be moved to Nestle plants in the Czech Republic, Poland and Bulgaria - after the factory in Newcastle is set to shut in Nestlés factory at Fawdon, Newcastle Upon Tyne, will shut in  Image: Rod Kirkpatrick F Stop PressByGraeme WhitfieldAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsNestle is shutting down a factory in the UK to start producing confectionary abroad.The former Rowntree factory in Newcastle will shut and switch to some production in eastern Europe in .At least  jobs will be lost and consultations with staff have moved to closure plans after Nestle rejected pleas from unions to reconsider, ChronicleLive reports. Production of popular items such as Fruit Pastilles, Toffee Crisps and mini eggs will be moved to Nestle plants in the Czech Republic, Poland and Bulgaria. While other items will be produced in Halax.  The factory, which first opened in , makes all the Rolos in the world and also produces a range of sweets that includes Caramac and Munchies. GMB national officer Ross Murdoch said: “Closing this profit-making site and shting production to Europe is completely unacceptable. This will have a devasting impact on workers and their families. “Meanwhile transporting finished products from sites in Europe back to the UK - where they are consumed - will result in signicant additional road and sea miles increasing pollution and environmental damage.  “GMB and Unite will now speak to members in Fawdon and find out what they want to do next. We will give them whatever support and resources they need to fight this.” Joe Clarke, a national officer at Unite the Union, said: “Unite and its membership are bitterly disappointed that alternative proposals to keep the site within Nestle Fawdon open have been rejected.  “We are currently seeking further information in relation to the proposal, and we will enter into dialogue on next steps imminently.” A Nestle spokesman said: “The consultation around the changes we proposed in April  is still ongoing. “We said from the outset that we wanted to provide adequate time and space for these discussions and it is only right that they are held directly with our employees and trade unions and not in public. It remains a priority to support our people and their families through this process and we thank everybody for their patience. “We will provide an update once the consultation is complete.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON UniteRowntree PLCNestle UK Ltd." data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Retired British Airways jet bought for £ transformed into £,-an-hour party planeThe British Airways Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space to host everything from private birthday parties to product launches and corporate eventsThe BA Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space Image: @negus   SWNSByTom Bevan:,  Feb  A classic  British Airways jet has undergone a dramatic transformation into a “party plane” which will be available for revellers to hire.The BA Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space to host everything from private birthday parties to product launches and corporate events, and is now sitting pretty at the privately-owned Cotswolds Airport near Wiltshire. It was bought for just £ in  by the airportaposs chief executive Suzannah Harvey when British Airways retired its fleet early due to the pandemic, and has been a labor of love ever since. Suzannah said: I paid a pound for her, and we have a certain obligation to maintain it as is practical for public use. The company has had to spend nearly £, getting her prepped and ready here, but I think itaposs money well spent and it preserves her for future generations.  Most of the original structure has stayed the same but the transformation has included stripping out the economy section to create the events space and turning the gallery into a bar. A full rewiring with custom lighting has been done while it also took one man a whole week and a half to give it a good clean inside and out. Suzannah described the renovation process as a “long old slog”.  “She came into us in October , and at the time I rather naively thought weaposd have her up and running by the following Easter,” she said. Weaposve had such tremendous support from everybody. All the contractors, all the people that have volunteered who are current BA  engineers - and here we are finally. “Sheaposs ready and sheaposs good to go. The Negus entered the British Airways fleet on  February , operating , flights - flying for , hours over nearly  million miles.  Its last passenger flight was from Miami to Heathrow on  April, .Anyone now wanting to host a party onboard will have to pay more than £, an hour but Suzannah said they had been inundated with enquiries - including from Netflix.Suzannah added: The vision has finally come to fruition, with overwhelming support from volunteers including current BA engineers and half a million pounds of investment later, Negus  is finally ready.  Preserved for many years to come and future generations, Negus is the only bespoke events  in the world. Cotswold Airport is family owned and operated and is the largest privately owned airport in Europe having a runway only m shorter than Bristol International. Suzannah said an app will soon be launched to enable the general public to book tours of the aircraft. story: Royal Mail postman can barely walk after accidentally eating four hash browniesA postman was filmed saying Im not right as he sat in a chair after accidentally eating hash brownies which Royal Mail had tried to deliver to an empty home, it is claimedThe postie was filmed saying Im not right as he sat down in the office Image: TwitterByKirsty CardReporterMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Feb Royal Mail has launched a probe after a postman who reportedly managed to aposaccidentally eat hash browniesapos was filmed staggering around in the street.Footage shared on social media showed the man barely able to stand up as he walked along a road in Clapham, London, the Daily Star reports. The laced brownies were allegedly stored by staff after they tried to deliver them to an empty home and there was noaddress on the parcel, according to posts on Instagram.It is not clear how the postman came into contact with the treats, which were kept inside a box labelled aposEdibles by Pablochocobarapos. Another man had to come and collect him from his delivery route as he was unable to move his cart, but when he got back to the office he was filmed sitting in a chair saying aposIaposm not right.apos A colleague is heard remarking that the poor postie had munched his way through two of the brownies, before the chap admits he actually had four. Text accompanying the Instagram Stories clip — which was later uploaded to TikTok by a dferent user — explains why the brownies had been eaten: We had a delivery of them with noaddress and the house was empty and they were in our office for a month so we opened them and they got given out. They were eaten between .-.am. The viral video has received over , likes on the app as Londoners found it hilarious that their postman had ended up in such a state. title: school makes parents sign contract
story: School makes parents sign contract to say homosexuality is a sin - or will expel kidsThe contract is lumping students who are unsure about their sexuality or unsure about their gender identity... with the likes paedophiles and adulterersFormer Citipointe Christian College student Felicity Myers Image: AAP PA ImagesByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA school has sparked outrage after asking parents to sign a contract saying that homosexuality is a sin or their child will be expelled. Despite the backlash, headteacher Brian Mulheran, of the Citipointe Christian College, has doubled down and given parents an extra two weeks to sign their children up. The contract was sent to families last Friday and said the college will only enrol the student on the basis of the gender that corresponds to their biological sex. It also asserted that homosexuality, along with bestiality, incest and paedophilia, was sinful. One teacher, who also has a student at the college, has already resigned saying young people within the LGBTQ+ community deserve to feel safe while at school. Helen Clapham Burns was also a teacher at the school in Carindale, Australia, but quit on Monday saying she couldnapost continue to work for a school that would do that to children.  Mrs Burns said: Iaposm heartbroken. I feel like Iaposve let them down that Iaposm having to leave. But I have to let those queer kids know that there are Christians out there that love them and arenapost hiding behind Bible verses and are letting them know that they are safe with me. As an educator, my priority is to make sure that each child that I interact with feels safe. When a child tells us, with tears in their eyes, that they donapost feel safe, what are we doing  Mr Mulheran made a video for parents about the contract. In it he said he had listened to their concerns and wanted them to make the right decisions for themselves. The declaration of faith has been in place for the whole of last year, he said.  We want families to consider this ethos so that they can make the right decisions for themselves. He added: We have always held these Christian beliefs and we have tried to be fair and transparent to everyone in our community by making them clear in the enrolment contract. We are seeking to maintain our Christian ethos and to give parents and students the right to make an informed choice about whether they can support and embrace our approach to Christian education. Citipointe does not judge students on their sexuality or gender identity and we would not make a decision about their enrolment in the College simply on that basis.  A group of parents has said they want to file a complaint to the Human Rights Commission, arguing they were not consulted about the contract and that the college was discriminating against students on the basis of sexuality and gender identity. One parent who is asked not to be named said: The contract they put out is so blatantly damaging to anyone within the school who identies within the LGBTQI umbrella are not of their highest concern. But nor is anybody  who believes in standing up against this kind of discrimination, because the contract makes it clear that any kind of act that goes against this belief is something that can be disciplined. Federal Member for Moncref, Angie Bell, told ABC Radio in Brisbane she disagreed with the college lumping students who are unsure about their sexuality or unsure about their gender identity ... with the likes paedophiles and adulterers. No school child should be discriminated against based on their sexual orientation, their gender identity, their pregnancy status, or their relationship status, which are the four elements that are in that section of the Sex Discrimination Act, she said.Religious organisations also have the right to practise their faith … without a doubt … notitaposs done in a discriminatory fashion. This is not  anymore … this is a new year, this is a new decade, this is a new Australia and there is no room. story: Two-legged dog who has never been loved is searching for a place to call homeLalia has been living on the streets of Cario unable to use her back leg - but Miracles Mission has stepped up to transform her le" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _streetdogJPG.jpg" width"" "" Lalia, a mixed-breed dog, has been living on the streets of Cario unable to use her back legs. ByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA two-legged dog who doesn’t know what it is like to be loved is desperately searching for a home. Lalia, a mixed-breed dog, has been living on the streets of Cario unable to use her back legs. One of her legs was so badly damaged that it had to be amputated, while the other still hangs lelessly on her body. It is unknown how long Lalia has been living like this - but Miracleaposs Mission has stepped up to transform her le. The animal welfare organisation, who work with sick, injured and disabled animals worldwide, wants to rehome Lalia in the UK - and already have a flight booked for her. However, as she has received no online interest from any potential owners, her spot on the plane might remain empty at take off.A statement on Twitter reads: “Laila will miss her flightwe donapost find a suitable foster this week.“She cannot thrive in a shelter environment - she really needs a home.” Lalia is currently being fostered in Egypt - but is ready to travel as soon as a new owner comes forward. A statement reads: “Laila is a sweet girl who gets around and will likely benefit from a set of wheels to aid her mobility on walks. “Laila is good with other dogs. She would rather not live with children or cats. “Shelter le is particularly dficult for dogs like Laila with disabilities, so we really would like for her to travel as soon as possible.  “She is incontinent and will require bladder expression three or four times a day. This is easy to do and we offer full training in this to all prospective foster and forever families.” Miracle’s Mission is a UK registered animal welfare charity who work predominantly in the UK, Borneo and Egypt. Founded by Victoria Bryceson in , they aim to provide safety and support to animals in need worldwide. A statement reads: “Our mission is to provide a place of safety for animals in danger, to educate on the needs of neutering both pets and strays and to neuter stray dogs and cats to prevent the birth of more animals onto the streets. We also rehabilitate and rehome dogs in need, often with disabilities, from our UK rescue base.”If you’re interested in rehoming Lalia, for either foster or adoption, please contact Miracle’s Mission viainfo@miraclesmission.org . To support the charity, visit their website viawww.miraclesmission.org . title: with cristiano ronaldo side pestered
story: With Cristiano Ronaldo on their side, pestered parents can win phone battleEva Simpson cheers on the Manchester United footballer who is refusing to spoil his young son with tech and gadgets. Cristiano Ronaldo said his -year-old son isn’t allowed a phoneCristiano Ronaldo is refusing to cave in Image: Visionhaus Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Feb |comments I don’t have much in ­common with Cristiano Ronaldo.He’s a multimillionaire ­footballer with luxurious homes across the world and an army of fans and followers on social media. I’m a mum working from a wobbly table in the kitchen. So I was surprised to find out there is one thing we agree on: our attitude towards ­children and gadgets.Earlier this week the Manchester United star revealed his -year-old son Cristiano Jnr – who presumably could have anything money can buy – isn’t allowed a phone, despite constantly pestering him for one.Ronaldo warned of the dangers of being “obsessed” with technology and shared a story that most parents with young children will know only too well – little ones demanding phones. Speaking about tech, Ronaldo said: “Definitely it helps a lot. It helped me and the people here, all the world, and I think we have to take advantage of that but we shouldn’t be obsessed with it.”  He went on: “My oldest child is going to be  years old soon and he asks me every time, ‘Daddy, can I have a phone, can I have a phone, can I have a phone ’ I say to him, ‘Cristiano, you have time.’” I can’t believe he’s been able to hold out for so long. My six-year-old asks, on an almost daily basis,he can have a phone, insisting all his friends have one. The answer is obviously no – he’s far too young and I know most of his friends don’t own one – but nonetheless it is a source of contention. The few times I’ve given him my smartphone to play games or watch a show on, there’s a full-blown meltdown when it comes to getting it back.  When I think about ­children and gadgets, I often recall the words of Steve Jobs, when he was askedhis kids loved one of his greatest inventions: the iPad.He said: “They haven’t used it. We limit the amount of technology our children use at home.” See, even the great Jobs didn’t let his kids loose on gadgets. Technology is important but it’s far better for kids to be creative, make up their own games and, where possible, play outside. That’s what childhood should be about, not being glued to a screen. So now when my son whines, I have the perfect reply. If it’s good enough for Ronaldo’s son not to have a phone, then it’s good enough for you. story: I lied to my family about my proposal - theyre fuming after drunkenly learning truthA man has revealed he lied to his family about proposing to his we and said they are mad and hurt after they discovered the truth via a drunken confessionThe man kept the details of his proposal a secret for five yearsImage: Getty Images Image SourceByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Feb |comments Getting engaged is said to be one of the happiest days of your le - usually falling shortly behind your actual wedding day and the birth of your children. But one man on Reddit has revealed he lied for five years about his own engagement, as he told his family he had proposed to his now-we during a romantic meal a few months after heaposd actually got down on one knee. The reason he lied  Because heaposd actually proposed during his own sisteraposs wedding. Sharing his story anonymously, the man explained his sister had enjoyed a lavish destination wedding five years ago that her husbandaposs parents had paid for and the location was so romantic he decided to pop the question to his girlfriend - and then hide it from his family.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. He said: My sister got married five years ago. Her husbandaposs parents were quite rich and they paid for a destination wedding for five days. They even paid for the flights and the stay for all the immediate family members. Back then, that was hugely romantic and it felt like a fairytale. Although we are doing much better financially now, back then I was sure that I would never be able to do something like that. I didnapost even plan to do this, but I was caught up in the moment and asked my girlfriend to marry me. She said yes but we did not say anything to anyone. I did not want to step on any toes. A few months later, I brought an engagement ring and we told everyone that I had proposed after a romantic meal at home and that was that. However, the cat was let out of the bag five years later when the family went on holiday to the same location, and the manaposs we spilt the beans to his sister while drunk.  He added: A few months ago, we went on a vacation to the same place my sister got married. It was my sister, her husband, her two kids, me, and my we. We were getting drunk and having fun when my we told them that I had proposed to her outside this very restaurant all those years ago. My sister was p***ed and she stormed out. My we feels guilty for letting the cat out of the bag. My brother-in-law also feels that it was cheap of me to use his parentsapos money for a proposal. The man said his sister is now refusing to talk to him - but he thinks she should let it go. He said: Itaposs been weeks and my sister is still cold towards us. I told her it happened years ago and to just let it go. She said that she is hurt, and that was supposed to be her fabulous wedding. She says that the place and time is now memorable to us as the place we agreed to get married and that it will never be remembered as the place she actually got married. She was very mad that I hurt her feelings and now I am just asking her to let it go. Commenters on the Reddit post were largely on the manaposs side, as they said he would have been out of lineheaposd proposed in front of his sisteraposs wedding guests, but doing so discreetly was fine. One said: Normally I’d say youaposre the a**hole, but you didn’t do it publicly in front of everyone. You did it privately. Nobody had hurt feelings until now. While another added: I came in here expecting to say you were in the wrong, but in this case, I think your sister is making too big a deal of this. And a third posted: Your sister is acting immature. Your secret proposal does not in any way affect her marriage or memories. news weird-news mcdonalds-fans-say-chicken-big-"McDonalds UK launch the new Chicken Big MacByJulia Banim:,  Feb |commentsThe McDonaldaposs Chicken Big Mac Burger has finally landed in the UK, and itaposs fair to say that it has some pretty big buns to fill.The classic Big Mac has been a staple of the Maccies menu since , with those two iconic beef patties seeing loyal customers through countless hangovers, Friday nights in, and bad days at work. Itaposs therefore somewhat unsurprising that, after breathless anticipation leading up to the launch, McDonaldaposs fans have been sharing their thoughts about the Chicken Big Mac Burger and whether or not it could ever live up to the instantly recognisable flavours of the OG.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Many reviews have so far been pretty positive, with ious happy customers hailing it in turn as a triumph,a banger, and the best thing since sliced bread. One particularly enamoured Instagram user wrote: I’ve been waiting for this day for so long that when my boyfriend suggested having the new Chicken Big Mac for dinner, of course, I wasn’t going to say no, It’s a solid   for me. It tastes incredible and needed to become a permanent addition to the menu.However, some have noted that itaposs quite a messy burger, with one person tweeting: chicken big mac is v delicious. but the chicken burgers are not the right shape for that stack. Absolute chaos eating it. All layers sliding. Another gave the gloried mayo chicken meal a so-so   ranking, remarking that their initial hesitations of the meal being a little dry do still stand, with the burger needing something extra to give it flavour and moisture. In a bid to combat said dryness - and in a move which could well help those grappling with the aforementioned sliding layers - one TikToker has advised their followers to dash the dry top bun, emphasising no one needs that in their lives. In a video that has since been viewed more than .K times at the time of writing, TikTok user Laura Crawford could be seen removing the seeded top bun before flipping the middle bun on top.Laura has declared the hack to be the best way to eat the Chicken Big Mac, and plenty of her followers are certainly interested in giving it a go. One even suggested replacing the top bun with a layer of fries, which may well be a step too far for some Maccies purists. Of course, numerous inevitable comparisons have been made to the beef Big Mac, with one huge fan asserting that ya don’t f*ck about with a classic. Others have argued that Big Mac sauce is much more suited towards beef than chicken, with one tweeting that it overpowers the chicken a bit. Another reflected that the burger would be better with the original McChicken sandwich Mayo in instead of the Big Mac sauce. However, in his recent review, the Mirroraposs Kyle OaposSullivan found that the sauce went very nicely indeed with the burger, writing: Just like any Big Mac, the first thing you taste is that creamy special sauce and it works incredibly well with the chicken. I was concerned about the Chicken Big Mac being too dry but to my surprise, it was moist enough and lashings of sauce were a bonus. Those keen to form their own opinions on the burger everyone is talking about will need to get down to their local drive-thru sharpish, with the temporary item only making a fleeting appearance on the menu up until March . What are your thoughts on the newly launched Chicken Big Mac Burger  Let us know in the comments below. title: mum cant believe cheek after
story: Mum cant believe the cheek after shes asked to pay to attend childs partyA mum was happy for her son to attend a friends birthday party but was later surprised to learn that she too had to attend, paying a full £ for an adult ticketShes not impressed she has to payImage: Getty ImagesByJulia Banim:,  Feb |commentsA mum has been surprised to learn, weeks after accepting the invite, that she is expected to attend the birthday party of her sonaposs friend, paying £ for the privilege. According to this mum, the party is due to take place this coming Sunday at an activity centre with a climbing wall, with the kids heading for some food afterwards.Taking to Mumsnet, the surprised mother explained that they accepted the invitation some weeks back, and have already bought a present and card.However, she was left a little taken aback after being sent an unexpected message from the birthday childaposs parent less than one week before the big day.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Calling upon her fellow mums for advice, she said: Weaposve been sent a message yesterday from birthday childaposs parent last night which says that all children under eight must be supervised by an adult each, which is ok with me I donapost mind stayingbut that in order to stay and supervise we have to buy a full-price adults ticket, which costs £! Wondering whether this was a usual request - especially when made so close to the big day - the slightly peeved parent admitted that it seems a bit of a cheek to me! In the comments, she went on to explain that it is only a small party of maybe eight or so children. All of the kids are under the age of eight, except for the birthday child, meaning all parents will have to stay and pay.She added: I suspect most parents were planning on staying regardless as theyaposre quite young but I donapost think anyone would have expected to fork out £ for the privilege! Many commenters completely understood her reservations, with one user even advising that she would call the place myself and check, addingtrue I would withdraw and do something  instead. Another confessed theyaposd be pretty shocked by that! wondering whether the parent has only just realised the cost oritaposs a case of poor communication from the venue. They added: Whenever weaposve been to birthday parties at soft play leisure centres activities etc., the cost of supervising and running the activity is covered by the parents, itaposs part of the party cost in my opinion. news world-news captain-cooks-ship-hms-endeavour-"Captain Cook: Wreckage confirmed as remains of EndeavourByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsCaptain Cook’s ship, HMS Endeavour, has been found at the bottom of the ocean almost  years after it sank. The wreckage of the British explorer’s ship has been sitting on the seafloor in US waters for two and a half centuries, but was finally discovered after a two decade search by archaeologists.It was discovered in Newport Habor, Rhode Island, where marine archaeologists have been investigating a number of th century shipwrecks. The Endeavour laid in its watery grave there thanks to British forces. During the American War of Independence in , the Brits purposely sank the ship. The archaeologists have been on site since , and today, the Australian National Maritime Museum chief executive Kevin Sumption confirmed that James Cook’s vessel had been identied.  Speaking to reporters, Sumption said: “Itaposs arguably one of the most important vessels in Australiaaposs maritime history. “I am satisfied that this is the final resting place of one of the most important and contentious vessels in Australiaaposs maritime history. “Based on archival and archaeological evidence, Iaposm convinced itaposs the Endeavour. “Itaposs an important historical moment, as this vesselaposs role in exploration, astronomy and science applies not just to Australia, but also Aotearoa New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States.”  However, one American expert who was involved in the discovery has said it is “premature” to definitely say this ship is the Endeavour. Dr Kathy Abbass, of Rhode Island Marine Archaeology Project , called the report “premature” and was left frustrated, accusing the Maritime Museum of being “in breach of the contract” after it claimed the news to the public. She told ABC: “What we see on the shipwreck site under study is consistent with what might be expected of the Endeavour, but there has been no indisputable data found to prove the site is that iconic vessel, and there are many unanswered questions that could overturn such an identication.  “RIMAP recognises the connections between Australian citizens of British descent and the Endeavour but RIMAPaposs conclusions will be driven by a proper scientic process and not Australian emotions or politics.” THe claims have been made that the shipwreck is the infamous Endeavour due to a number of reasons. The structural details and shape of the ship closely match historic plans of the Endeavour.  Specically, the construction of the keel on the bottom of the ship, and joinery on its bow at the front, are identical to those seen in th century plans. On top of that, theof the hull of the wreckage is almost identical to that recorded for the Endeavour. Also historical evidence suggested the ship was sunk in the area, along with four other British ships. However, only  per cent of the vessel remains and researchers are now working to protect and preserve what’s left.  Sumption added: “We will continue to investigate and look closely with maritime experts at Rhode Island about the future of this site and what should happen to this site but certainly protection is what weaposre working towards right now.” Researchers are currently finalising their report on the find, which is still ye to be peer reviewed and published. The Endeavour originally was launched in  under the name the Earl of Pembroke. It wasn’t until  that it was renamed and prepared for its scientic voyage to the Pacic. title: loyal dog sits alone bench
story: Loyal dog sits alone by bench where his homeless owner died outside hospitalThe dog refused to leave its -year-old homeless owners side after he died on a bench outside the Rio Piedras Medical Centre in the Puerto Rican capital of San JuanThe loyal pooch stayed by the bench where its owner died even after his body had been taken away Image: CENByLee BullenMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsThese images show a loyal dog sitting on the spot where its homeless owner died on a bench outside a hospital. The moving scene took place outside Rio Piedras Medical Centre in the Puerto Rican capital San Juan on the morning of February . According to the news site El Universal, the -year-old homeless man passed away in the night and the dog stayed by his side. The loyal pooch even remained on the bench as personnel from the Institute of Forensic Sciencestook the body away, gazing at the morgue vehicle as it disappeared from view. However, medical staff took a liking to the dog, and Dr Jose Antonio Herrera Dalmau reportedly decided to adopt the ownerless animal. He told the newspaper El Nuevo Dia: I have already made an appointment to see a vet because the dog has a leg injury. It is not broken, but it has an injury. The hospital doctor added that he was thinking of calling the pooch Leo. He said he was told about the dog by a colleague and went outside to take a look.The doctor, who says he is a dog lover, explained that Leo looks a lot like a pet pooch he had several years ago called Reina. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Dr Herrera Dalmau also said that he tried to make the dog follow him onto the bus, but it refused to leave the bench, apparently waiting for its dead owner, so he had to carry the animal home in his arms. It comes just weeks after a hero dog saved its owneraposs le by keeping him warm for  hours after he fell ft down a mountain slope.Grga Brkic was with two other hikers in Croatiaaposs Velebit mountain range when he slipped down the slope and was unresponsive. The two other hikers alerted mountain rescue and  responders found Brkic with North tightly curled around him for warmth. In a statement on Facebook, the Croatian mountain rescue service said: “Friendship and love between man and dog know no boundaries. “North passed without injuries, but his friend, a young mountaineer, was not so lucky. He curled up with him and warmed him with his body. “His loyalty did not stop even from the arrival of the saviour, he was one of us guarding his man for  hours.” Velebit is the largest mountain range in Croatia at nearly , metres above sea level. Mountain rescue have warned against taking dogs for hikes in poor conditions particularly during the winter months. Mr Brkic described his dog as a “real miracle”, reports the Express. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. All of Argyll and Bute#s secondary schools were allocated up to  places on the programme.#Activities were delivered to achieve increased confidence, self-esteem and resilience, building le-skills, encouraging self-respect, introducing coping mechanisms, improving mental, physical and emotional wellbeing and developing aspirations for the future.#There were many outcomes achieved and positive impacts which included  young people taking part in outdoor learning experiences that challenged them.#Forty five young people gained SQA Health and Wellbeing awards,  young people achieved Dynamic Youth Awards and  young people achieved Hi awards.#Eighty per cent reported their wellbeing improved,  per cent increased their re-engagement with education and  per cent saw their choices and behaviour improve.#The report also gave an update on the No-one Left Behind employability delivery model which continues to operate in the area.The spokesperson added: #We continued working with learners through another year of Covid lockdown [in  ] and supported a further  people via online and non-face to face provision to help them develop their skills and move into positive destinations, improve their chances of employment, address barriers and challenges and gain accredited qualications.#This resulted in six learners entering further education and five people entering into employment.
